         316
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zammit_3-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Zammit-3">
           [3]
          </a>
         </sup>
         km
         <sup>
          2
         </sup>
         (122 sq mi) (
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">
          186th
         </a>
         )
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedbottomrow">

      <p>
       <span style="font-size: small;">
        <span id="coordinates">
         <a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">
          Coordinates
         </a>
         :
         <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion">
          <a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Malta&amp;params=35_53_N_14_30_E_region:MT_scale:300000">
           <span class="geo-default">
            <span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
             <span class="latitude">
              35°53′N
             </span>
             <span class="longitude">
              14°30′E
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
           <span class="geo-multi-punct">
            ﻿ / ﻿
           </span>
           <span class="geo-nondefault">
            <span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
             35.883°N 14.500°E
            </span>
            <span style="display:none">
             ﻿ /
             <span class="geo">
              35.883; 14.500
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </a>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </p>
      <p>
       <b>
        Malta
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="'m' in 'my'">
            m
           </span>
           <span title="/ɒ/: 'o' in 'body'">
            ɒ
           </span>
           <span title="'l' in 'lie'">
            l
           </span>
           <span title="'t' in 'tie'">
            t
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
          </span>
          /
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="nowrap">
         (
         <span class="unicode haudio">
          <span class="fn">
           <span style="white-space:nowrap">
            <a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Malta.ogg" title="About this sound">
             <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
            </a>
           </span>
           <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/23/En-us-Malta.ogg" title="En-us-Malta.ogg">
            listen
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ;
       <small>
        Maltese:
       </small>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Maltese" title="Help:IPA/Maltese">
         [ˈmɐltɐ]
        </a>
       </span>
       ), officially known as the
       <b>
        Republic of Malta
       </b>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">
        Maltese
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="mt">
         Repubblika ta' Malta
        </span>
       </i>
       ), is a Southern European
       <a href="/wiki/Island_country" title="Island country">
        island country
       </a>
       consisting of an
       <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">
        archipelago
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
        Mediterranean Sea
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
        <a href="#cite_note-9">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It lies 80 km (50 mi) south of Italy, 284 km (176 mi) east of
       <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">
        Tunisia
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ashby_10-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ashby-10">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 333 km (207 mi) north of
       <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">
        Libya
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
        <a href="#cite_note-11">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country covers just over 316 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (122 sq mi),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zammit_3-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Zammit-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with a population of just under 450,000,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Estimated_4-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Estimated-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       making it one of the world's
       <a href="/wiki/Microstate" title="Microstate">
        smallest
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
        <a href="#cite_note-12">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
        <a href="#cite_note-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
        <a href="#cite_note-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population_density" title="List of countries by population density">
        most densely populated
       </a>
       countries. The capital of Malta is
       <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">
        Valletta
       </a>
       , which at 0.8 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       , is the smallest
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_capital" title="National capital">
        national capital
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       by area.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Malta has two official languages which are Maltese and English. However, the Maltese language is also regarded as the national language of the island.
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta's location in the middle of the Mediterranean
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
        <a href="#cite_note-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       has historically given it great strategic importance as a naval base, and a succession of powers, including the
       <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">
        Phoenicians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Carthage" title="Ancient Carthage">
        Carthaginians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">
        Greeks
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
        Romans
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Greeks" title="Byzantine Greeks">
        Byzantines
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Sicily" title="Emirate of Sicily">
        Arabs
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/County_of_Sicily" title="County of Sicily">
        Normans
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sicily" title="Kingdom of Sicily">
        Sicilians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Spain" title="Habsburg Spain">
        Spanish
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">
        Knights of St. John
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/French_First_Republic" title="French First Republic">
        French
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">
        British
       </a>
       have ruled the islands.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/George_VI" title="George VI">
        King George VI
       </a>
       of the United Kingdom
       <a href="/wiki/Award_of_the_George_Cross_to_Malta" title="Award of the George Cross to Malta">
        awarded the George Cross to Malta
       </a>
       in 1942 for the then British colony's bravery in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">
        Second World War
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
        <a href="#cite_note-18">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/George_Cross" title="George Cross">
        George Cross
       </a>
       continues to appear on Malta's national flag.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Under the Malta Independence Act, passed by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Parliament" title="British Parliament">
        British Parliament
       </a>
       in 1964, Malta gained independence from the United Kingdom as an independent sovereign
       <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realm" title="Commonwealth realm">
        Commonwealth realm
       </a>
       , officially known from 1964 to 1974 as the
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Malta" title="State of Malta">
        State of Malta
       </a>
       , with
       <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">
        Elizabeth II
       </a>
       as its head of state.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country became a republic in 1974, and although no longer a Commonwealth realm, remains a
       <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Member states of the Commonwealth of Nations">
        member state
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">
        Commonwealth of Nations
       </a>
       . Malta was admitted to the United Nations in 1964 and to the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       in 2004; in 2008, it became part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
        Eurozone
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta has a long Christian legacy and its
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Malta" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Malta">
        Archdiocese of Malta
       </a>
       is claimed to be an
       <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_see" title="Apostolic see">
        apostolic see
       </a>
       because, according to
       <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">
        Acts of the Apostles
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">
        St Paul
       </a>
       was shipwrecked on "Melita", now widely taken to be Malta.
       <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">
        Catholicism
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">
        official
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Malta" title="Religion in Malta">
        religion in Malta
       </a>
       . However, the Constitution also states that all persons in Malta are entitled to the full freedom of conscience and enjoy the free exercise of their respective mode of religious worship.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_22-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cia-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-legal-malta_23-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-legal-malta-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta is a popular tourist destination with its warm climate, numerous recreational areas, and architectural and historical monuments, including three
       <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
        UNESCO World Heritage Sites
       </a>
       :
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hypogeum_of_%C4%A6al-Saflieni" title="Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni">
        Ħal Saflieni Hypogeum
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">
        Valletta
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and seven
       <a href="/wiki/Megalithic_Temples_of_Malta" title="Megalithic Temples of Malta">
        megalithic temples
       </a>
       , which are some of the oldest free-standing structures in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
        <a href="#cite_note-26">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
        <a href="#cite_note-27">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-b1_28-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-b1-28">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>

      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
        Etymology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Etymology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       The origin of the term
       <i>
        Malta
       </i>
       is uncertain, and the modern-day variation derives from the
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">
        Maltese language
       </a>
       . The most common
       <a href="/wiki/Etymology" title="Etymology">
        etymology
       </a>
       is that the word
       <i>
        Malta
       </i>
       derives from the
       <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">
        Greek
       </a>
       word
       <span lang="grc">
        μέλι
       </span>
       ,
       <i>
        meli
       </i>
       , 'honey'.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
        <a href="#cite_note-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The ancient Greeks called the island
       <span lang="grc">
        Μελίτη
       </span>
       (
       <i>
        Melitē
       </i>
       ) meaning '
       <a href="/wiki/Honey" title="Honey">
        honey
       </a>
       -sweet', possibly for Malta's unique production of honey; an
       <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">
        endemic
       </a>
       subspecies of
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_honey_bee" title="Maltese honey bee">
        bee
       </a>
       lives on the island.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Romans went on to call the island
       <i>
        Melita
       </i>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
        <a href="#cite_note-31">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which can be considered either as a
       <a href="/wiki/Latinisation_of_names" title="Latinisation of names">
        latinisation
       </a>
       of the Greek
       <span lang="grc">
        Μελίτη
       </span>
       or the adaptation of the
       <a href="/wiki/Doric_Greek" title="Doric Greek">
        Doric Greek
       </a>
       pronunciation of the same word
       <span lang="grc">
        Μελίτα
       </span>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
        <a href="#cite_note-32">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Another conjecture suggests that the word
       <i>
        Malta
       </i>
       comes from the
       <a href="/wiki/Phoenician_language" title="Phoenician language">
        Phoenician
       </a>
       word
       <i>
        Maleth
       </i>
       'a haven'
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
        <a href="#cite_note-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or 'port'
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in reference to Malta's many bays and
       <a href="/wiki/Cove" title="Cove">
        coves
       </a>
       . Few other etymological mentions appear in classical literature, with the term
       <i>
        Malta
       </i>
       appearing in its present form in the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Antonine_Itinerary" title="Antonine Itinerary">
         Antonine Itinerary
        </a>
       </i>
       (Itin. Marit. p. 518; Sil. Ital. xiv. 251).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
        <a href="#cite_note-35">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Malta" title="History of Malta">
        History of Malta
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Maltese_history" title="Timeline of Maltese history">
        Timeline of Maltese history
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Malta has been inhabited from around 5200 BC, since the arrival of settlers from the island of
       <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">
        Sicily
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gozo_36-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-gozo-36">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A significant prehistoric
       <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
        Neolithic
       </a>
       culture marked by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Megalithic" title="Megalithic">
        Megalithic
       </a>
       structures, which date back to c. 3600 BC, existed on the islands, as evidenced by the temples of
       <a href="/wiki/Mnajdra" title="Mnajdra">
        Mnajdra
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ggantija" title="Ggantija">
        Ggantija
       </a>
       and others. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phoenicians" title="Phoenicians">
        Phoenicians
       </a>
       colonised Malta between 800–700 BC, bringing their
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semitic_language" title="Semitic language">
        Semitic language
       </a>
       and culture.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       They used the islands as an outpost from which they expanded sea explorations and trade in the Mediterranean until their successors, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carthaginians" title="Carthaginians">
        Carthaginians
       </a>
       , were ousted by the
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
        Romans
       </a>
       in 216 BC with the help of the Maltese inhabitants, under whom Malta became a
       <a href="/wiki/Municipium" title="Municipium">
        municipium
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.co.uk_38-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-books.google.co.uk-38">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       After a period of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine_empire" title="Byzantine empire">
        Byzantine
       </a>
       rule (4th to 9th century) and a probable sack by the
       <a href="/wiki/Vandals" title="Vandals">
        Vandals
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the islands were invaded by the
       <a href="/wiki/Aghlabids" title="Aghlabids">
        Aghlabids
       </a>
       in AD 870. The fate of the population after the Arab invasion is unclear but it seems the islands may have been completely depopulated and were likely to have been repopulated in the beginning of the second millennium by settlers from Arab-ruled Sicily who spoke
       <a href="/wiki/Siculo-Arabic" title="Siculo-Arabic">
        Siculo-Arabic
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_40-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-40">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Muslim rule was ended by the
       <a href="/wiki/Normans" title="Normans">
        Normans
       </a>
       who conquered the island in 1091. The islands were completely re-Christianised by 1249.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
        <a href="#cite_note-41">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The islands were part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sicily" title="Kingdom of Sicily">
        Kingdom of Sicily
       </a>
       until 1530, and were briefly controlled by the
       <a href="/wiki/Capetian_House_of_Anjou" title="Capetian House of Anjou">
        Capetian House of Anjou
       </a>
       . In 1530
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charles_I_of_Spain" title="Charles I of Spain">
        Charles I of Spain
       </a>
       gave the Maltese islands to the
       <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">
        Order of Knights of the Hospital of St John of Jerusalem
       </a>
       in perpetual lease.
      </p>
      <p>
       The French under
       <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">
        Napoleon
       </a>
       took hold of the Maltese islands in 1798, although with the aid of the British the Maltese were able to oust French control two years later. The inhabitants subsequently asked Britain to assume sovereignty over the islands under the conditions laid out in a Declaration of Rights,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
        <a href="#cite_note-42">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       stating that "his Majesty has no right to cede these Islands to any power...if he chooses to withdraw his protection, and abandon his sovereignty, the right of electing another sovereign, or of the governing of these Islands, belongs to us, the inhabitants and aborigines alone, and without control." As part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1814)" title="Treaty of Paris (1814)">
        Treaty of Paris (1814)
       </a>
       Malta became a British colony, ultimately rejecting an attempted
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Malta#Attempted_integration_with_the_United_Kingdom" title="History of Malta">
        integration with the United Kingdom
       </a>
       in 1956.
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta became independent on 21 September 1964 (
       <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(Malta)" title="Independence Day (Malta)">
        Independence Day
       </a>
       ). Under its 1964 constitution Malta initially retained Queen
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom">
        Elizabeth II
       </a>
       as
       <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_Malta" title="Queen of Malta">
        Queen of Malta
       </a>
       , with a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Governor-General" title="Governor-General">
        Governor-General
       </a>
       exercising executive authority on her behalf. On 13 December 1974 (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_Day_(Malta)" title="Republic Day (Malta)">
        Republic Day
       </a>
       ) it became a republic within the
       <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">
        Commonwealth
       </a>
       , with the
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Malta" title="President of Malta">
        President
       </a>
       as
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
        head of state
       </a>
       . On 31 March 1979 Malta saw the withdrawal of the last British troops and the
       <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">
        Royal Navy
       </a>
       from Malta. This day is known as
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_Day_(Malta)" title="Freedom Day (Malta)">
        Freedom Day
       </a>
       and Malta declared itself as a neutral and non-aligned. Malta joined the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       on 1 May 2004 and joined the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
        Eurozone
       </a>
       on 1 January 2008.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">
        Prehistory
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Prehistory">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Megalithic_Temples_of_Malta" title="Megalithic Temples of Malta">
        Megalithic Temples of Malta
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hypogeum_of_%C4%A6al-Saflieni" title="Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni">
        Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/G%C4%A7ar_Dalam" title="Għar Dalam">
        Għar Dalam
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Pottery" title="Pottery">
        Pottery
       </a>
       found by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archaeologists" title="Archaeologists">
        archaeologists
       </a>
       at the
       <a href="/wiki/Skorba_Temples" title="Skorba Temples">
        Skorba Temples
       </a>
       resembles that found in Italy, and suggests that the Maltese islands were first settled in 5200 BCE mainly by
       <a href="/wiki/Stone_Age" title="Stone Age">
        Stone Age
       </a>
       hunters or farmers who had arrived from the Italian island of
       <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">
        Sicily
       </a>
       , possibly the
       <a href="/wiki/Sicani" title="Sicani">
        Sicani
       </a>
       . The extinction of the
       <a href="/wiki/Hippopotamus_melitensis" title="Hippopotamus melitensis">
        dwarf hippos
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Palaeoloxodon_falconeri" title="Palaeoloxodon falconeri">
        dwarf elephants
       </a>
       has been linked to the earliest arrival of humans on Malta.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
        <a href="#cite_note-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Prehistoric farming settlements dating to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Neolithic" title="Early Neolithic">
        Early Neolithic
       </a>
       period were discovered in open areas and also in caves, such as
       <a href="/wiki/G%C4%A7ar_Dalam" title="Għar Dalam">
        Għar Dalam
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Skeates2010_44-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Skeates2010-44">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Sicani" title="Sicani">
        Sicani
       </a>
       were the only tribe known to have inhabited the island at this time
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gozo_36-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-gozo-36">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
        <a href="#cite_note-45">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and are generally regarded as being closely related to the
       <a href="/wiki/Iberians" title="Iberians">
        Iberians
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
        <a href="#cite_note-46">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The population on Malta grew
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cereals" title="Cereals">
        cereals
       </a>
       , raised livestock and, in common with other ancient Mediterranean cultures, worshiped a
       <a href="/wiki/Mother_goddess" title="Mother goddess">
        fertility figure
       </a>
       represented in Maltese prehistoric artefacts exhibiting the proportions seen in similar statuettes, including the
       <a href="/wiki/Venus_of_Willendorf" title="Venus of Willendorf">
        Venus of Willendorf
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ggantija_Temples,_Xaghra,_Gozo.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2581" data-file-width="3871" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Ggantija_Temples%2C_Xaghra%2C_Gozo.jpg/220px-Ggantija_Temples%2C_Xaghra%2C_Gozo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Ggantija_Temples%2C_Xaghra%2C_Gozo.jpg/330px-Ggantija_Temples%2C_Xaghra%2C_Gozo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Ggantija_Temples%2C_Xaghra%2C_Gozo.jpg/440px-Ggantija_Temples%2C_Xaghra%2C_Gozo.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ggantija_Temples,_Xaghra,_Gozo.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/%C4%A0gantija" title="Ġgantija">
          Ġgantija
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Megalith" title="Megalith">
          megalithic
         </a>
         temple complex
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_16_Mnajdra.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6096" data-file-width="4188" height="247" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Malta_16_Mnajdra.jpg/170px-Malta_16_Mnajdra.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Malta_16_Mnajdra.jpg/255px-Malta_16_Mnajdra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Malta_16_Mnajdra.jpg/340px-Malta_16_Mnajdra.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_16_Mnajdra.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The temple complex of
         <a href="/wiki/Mnajdra" title="Mnajdra">
          Mnajdra
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Pottery from the Għar Dalam phase is similar to pottery found in
       <a href="/wiki/Agrigento" title="Agrigento">
        Agrigento
       </a>
       , Sicily. A culture of
       <a href="/wiki/Megalith" title="Megalith">
        megalithis
       </a>
       temple builders then either supplanted or arose from this early period. Around the time of 3500 BCE, these people built some of the oldest existing free-standing structures in the world in the form of the megalithic
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%A0gantija" title="Ġgantija">
        Ġgantija
       </a>
       temples on
       <a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">
        Gozo
       </a>
       ;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-otsf_47-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-otsf-47">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       other early temples include those at
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%A6a%C4%A1ar_Qim" title="Ħaġar Qim">
        Ħaġar Qim
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Mnajdra" title="Mnajdra">
        Mnajdra
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-b1_28-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-b1-28">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
        <a href="#cite_note-48">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
        <a href="#cite_note-49">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The temples have distinctive architecture, typically a complex trefoil design, and were used from 4000 to 2500 BCE. Animal bones and a knife found behind a removable altar stone suggest that temple rituals included
       <a href="/wiki/Animal_sacrifice" title="Animal sacrifice">
        animal sacrifice
       </a>
       . Tentative information suggests that the sacrifices were made to the goddess of fertility, whose statue is now in the National Museum of Archaeology in Valletta.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The culture apparently disappeared from the Maltese Islands around 2500 BC. Archaeologists speculate that the temple builders fell victim to famine or disease, but this is not certain.
      </p>
      <p>
       Another archaeological feature of the Maltese Islands often attributed to these ancient builders is equidistant uniform grooves dubbed "cart tracks" or "cart ruts" which can be found in several locations throughout the islands, with the most prominent being those found in
       <a href="/wiki/Misra%C4%A7_G%C4%A7ar_il-Kbir" title="Misraħ Għar il-Kbir">
        Misraħ Għar il-Kbir
       </a>
       , which is informally known as "Clapham Junction". These may have been caused by wooden-wheeled carts eroding soft limestone.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
        <a href="#cite_note-52">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       After 2500 BCE, the Maltese Islands were depopulated for several decades until the arrival of a new influx of
       <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">
        Bronze Age
       </a>
       immigrants, a culture that
       <a href="/wiki/Cremation" title="Cremation">
        cremated
       </a>
       its dead and introduced smaller megalithic structures called
       <a href="/wiki/Dolmen" title="Dolmen">
        dolmens
       </a>
       to Malta.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In most cases there are small chambers here, with the cover made of a large slab placed on upright stones. They are claimed to belong to a population certainly different from that which built the previous megalithic temples. It is presumed the population arrived from
       <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">
        Sicily
       </a>
       because of the similarity of Maltese dolmens to some small constructions found on the largest island of the Mediterranean sea.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Piccolo-dolmens_54-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Piccolo-dolmens-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Greeks.2C_Phoenicians.2C_Carthaginians_and_Romans">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Greeks,_Phoenicians,_Carthaginians_and_Romans">
        Greeks, Phoenicians, Carthaginians and Romans
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Greeks, Phoenicians, Carthaginians and Romans">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Magna_Graecia" title="Magna Graecia">
        Magna Graecia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">
        Phoenicia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cippi_of_Melqart" title="Cippi of Melqart">
        Cippi of Melqart
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
        Ancient Rome
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sicilia_(Roman_province)" title="Sicilia (Roman province)">
        Sicilia (Roman province)
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
        Byzantine Empire
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Phoenician traders
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ndmh_55-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ndmh-55">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
       colonised the islands sometime after 1,000 BCE
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ashby_10-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ashby-10">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
       as a stop on their trade routes from the eastern
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
        Mediterranean
       </a>
       to
       <a href="/wiki/Cornwall" title="Cornwall">
        Cornwall
       </a>
       , joining the natives on the island.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
        <a href="#cite_note-56">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Phoenicians inhabited the area now known as
       <a href="/wiki/Mdina" title="Mdina">
        Mdina
       </a>
       , and its surrounding town of
       <a href="/wiki/Rabat,_Malta" title="Rabat, Malta">
        Rabat
       </a>
       , which they called
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Melite_(ancient_city)" title="Melite (ancient city)">
         Maleth
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
        <a href="#cite_note-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cassar53–55_58-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cassar53–55-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
        Romans
       </a>
       , who also much later inhabited Mdina, referred to it (and the island) as
       <i>
        Melita
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Roman_Malta.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="391" data-file-width="500" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Roman_Malta.jpg/220px-Roman_Malta.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Roman_Malta.jpg/330px-Roman_Malta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Roman_Malta.jpg/440px-Roman_Malta.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Roman_Malta.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
          Roman
         </a>
         mosaic from the
         <a href="/wiki/Domvs_Romana" title="Domvs Romana">
          Domvs Romana
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After the
       <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Tyre_(332_BC)" title="Siege of Tyre (332 BC)">
        fall of Phoenicia
       </a>
       in 332 BCE, the area came under the control of
       <a href="/wiki/Carthage" title="Carthage">
        Carthage
       </a>
       , a former Phoenician colony.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ashby_10-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-ashby-10">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maltihist_59-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-maltihist-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During this time the people on Malta mainly cultivated
       <a href="/wiki/Olive" title="Olive">
        olives
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ceratonia_siliqua" title="Ceratonia siliqua">
        carob
       </a>
       and produced textiles.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maltihist_59-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-maltihist-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       During the
       <a href="/wiki/First_Punic_War" title="First Punic War">
        First Punic War
       </a>
       , the island was conquered after harsh fighting by
       <a href="/wiki/Marcus_Atilius_Regulus" title="Marcus Atilius Regulus">
        Marcus Atilius Regulus
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ei_60-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ei-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After the failure of his expedition, the island fell back in the hands of Carthage, only to be conquered again in 218 BC, during the
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Punic_War" title="Second Punic War">
        Second Punic War
       </a>
       , by Roman Consul
       <a href="/wiki/Tiberius_Sempronius_Longus_(consul_218_BC)" title="Tiberius Sempronius Longus (consul 218 BC)">
        Tiberius Sempronius Longus
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ei_60-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ei-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since then, Malta became
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Civitas" title="Civitas">
         Foederata Civitas
        </a>
       </i>
       , a designation that meant it was exempt from paying
       <a href="/wiki/Tribute" title="Tribute">
        tribute
       </a>
       or the rule of
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_law" title="Roman law">
        Roman law
       </a>
       , and fell within the jurisdiction of
       <a href="/wiki/Sicilia_(Roman_province)" title="Sicilia (Roman province)">
        the province of Sicily
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Punic influence, however, remained vibrant on the islands with the famous
       <a href="/wiki/Cippi_of_Melqart" title="Cippi of Melqart">
        Cippi of Melqart
       </a>
       , pivotal in deciphering the
       <a href="/wiki/Punic_language" title="Punic language">
        Punic language
       </a>
       , dedicated in the 2nd century BCE.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
        <a href="#cite_note-61">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Also the local Roman coinage, which ceased in the 1st century BCE,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cassar56–57_63-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cassar56–57-63">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       indicates the slow pace of the island's Romanization, since the very last locally minted coins still bear inscriptions in
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">
        Ancient Greek
       </a>
       on the obverse (like "ΜΕΛΙΤΑΙΩ", meaning "of the Maltese") and Punic motifs, showing the resistance of the Greek and Punic cultures.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Greeks settled in the Maltese islands since circa 700 BCE, as testified by several architectural remains, and remained throughout the Roman dominium.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 1st century BCE, Roman Senator and orator
       <a href="/wiki/Cicero" title="Cicero">
        Cicero
       </a>
       commented on the importance of the
       <a href="/wiki/Tas-Sil%C4%A1" title="Tas-Silġ">
        Temple of Juno
       </a>
       , and on the extravagant behaviour of the Roman governor of Sicily,
       <a href="/wiki/Verres" title="Verres">
        Verres
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vm_66-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-vm-66">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the 1st century BC the island was mentioned by
       <a href="/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder" title="Pliny the Elder">
        Pliny the Elder
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Diodorus_Siculus" title="Diodorus Siculus">
        Diodorus Siculus
       </a>
       : the latter praised its harbours, the wealth of its inhabitants, its lavishly decorated houses and the quality of its textile products. In the 2nd century, Emperor
       <a href="/wiki/Hadrian" title="Hadrian">
        Hadrian
       </a>
       (r. 117–38) upgraded the status of Malta to
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Municipium" title="Municipium">
         municipium
        </a>
       </i>
       or free town: the island local affairs were administered by four
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Duumviri" title="Duumviri">
         quattuorviri iuri dicundo
        </a>
       </i>
       and a municipal senate, while a Roman
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Procurator_(Roman)" title="Procurator (Roman)">
        procurator
       </a>
       , living in
       <a href="/wiki/Mdina" title="Mdina">
        Mdina
       </a>
       , represented the
       <a href="/wiki/Proconsul" title="Proconsul">
        proconsul
       </a>
       of Sicily.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ei_60-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-ei-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 58 AD,
       <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">
        Paul the Apostle
       </a>
       was washed up on the islands together with
       <a href="/wiki/Luke_the_Evangelist" title="Luke the Evangelist">
        Luke the Evangelist
       </a>
       after their ship was wrecked on the islands.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ei_60-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-ei-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">
        Paul the Apostle
       </a>
       remained on the islands three months, preaching the Christian faith, which has since thrived on Malta.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ei_60-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-ei-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 395, when the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Division_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="Division of the Roman Empire">
        Roman Empire was divided for the last time
       </a>
       at the death of
       <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">
        Theodosius I
       </a>
       , Malta, following Sicily, fell under the control of the
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">
        Western Roman Empire
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the
       <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">
        Migration Period
       </a>
       as the
       <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">
        Western Roman Empire declined
       </a>
       , Malta came under attack and was conquered or occupied a number of times.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cassar56–57_63-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-cassar56–57-63">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       From 454 to 464 the islands was subdued by the
       <a href="/wiki/Vandals" title="Vandals">
        Vandals
       </a>
       , and after 464 by the
       <a href="/wiki/Ostrogoths" title="Ostrogoths">
        Ostrogoths
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ei_60-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-ei-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 533
       <a href="/wiki/Belisarius" title="Belisarius">
        Belisarius
       </a>
       , on his way to conquer the
       <a href="/wiki/Vandal_Kingdom" title="Vandal Kingdom">
        Vandal Kingdom
       </a>
       in North Africa, reunited the islands under Imperial (
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
        Eastern
       </a>
       ) rule.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ei_60-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-ei-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Little is known about the Byzantine rule in Malta: the island depended on the
       <a href="/wiki/Sicily_(theme)" title="Sicily (theme)">
        theme of Sicily
       </a>
       and had Greek Governors and a small Greek garrison.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ei_60-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-ei-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       While the bulk of population continued to be constituted by the old, Latinized dwellers, during this period its religious allegiance oscillated between the Pope and the
       <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople">
        Patriarch of Constantinople
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ei_60-8">
        <a href="#cite_note-ei-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Byzantine rule introduced
       <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">
        Greek
       </a>
       families to the Maltese collective.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
        <a href="#cite_note-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Malta remained under the
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
        Byzantine Empire
       </a>
       until 870, when it fell to the
       <a href="/wiki/Arabs" title="Arabs">
        Arabs
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ei_60-9">
        <a href="#cite_note-ei-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
        <a href="#cite_note-69">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Arab_period_and_the_Middle_Ages">
        Arab period and the Middle Ages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Arab period and the Middle Ages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Byzantine_wars" title="Arab–Byzantine wars">
        Arab–Byzantine wars
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Sicily" title="Emirate of Sicily">
        Emirate of Sicily
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mahmuna_Tombstone.jpeg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="761" data-file-width="729" height="230" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Mahmuna_Tombstone.jpeg/220px-Mahmuna_Tombstone.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Mahmuna_Tombstone.jpeg/330px-Mahmuna_Tombstone.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Mahmuna_Tombstone.jpeg/440px-Mahmuna_Tombstone.jpeg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mahmuna_Tombstone.jpeg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Majmuna_Stone" title="Majmuna Stone">
          Majmuna Stone
         </a>
         , a Roman period marble stone, was reused as a 12th-century tombstone believed to have been found in
         <a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">
          Gozo
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Malta became involved in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Byzantine_Wars" title="Arab–Byzantine Wars">
        Arab–Byzantine Wars
       </a>
       , and the conquest of Malta is closely linked with
       <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Sicily" title="Muslim conquest of Sicily">
        that of Sicily
       </a>
       that began in 827 after admiral
       <a href="/wiki/Euphemius_(Sicily)" title="Euphemius (Sicily)">
        Euphemius
       </a>
       ' betrayal of his fellow Byzantines, requesting that the
       <a href="/wiki/Aghlabids" title="Aghlabids">
        Aghlabids
       </a>
       invade the island.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stan_70-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-stan-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Muslim chronicler and geographer
       <a href="/wiki/Kitab_al-Rawd_al-Mitar" title="Kitab al-Rawd al-Mitar">
        al-Himyari
       </a>
       recounts that in 870 CE, following
       <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Melite_(870)" title="Siege of Melite (870)">
        a violent struggle
       </a>
       against the occupying Byzantines, the Arab invaders, first led by Halaf al-Hadim, and later by Sawada ibn Muhammad,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Travel_Malta_71-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Travel_Malta-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       looted and pillaged the island, destroying the most important buildings, and leaving it practically uninhabited until it was recolonised by the Arabs from Sicily in 1048–1049 AD.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Travel_Malta_71-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Travel_Malta-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is uncertain whether this new settlement took place as a consequence of demographic expansion in Sicily, as a result of a higher standard of living in Sicily (in which case the recolonisation may have taken place a few decades earlier), or as a result of civil war which broke out among the Arab rulers of Sicily in 1038.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
        <a href="#cite_note-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Arabs
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_Agricultural_Revolution" title="Arab Agricultural Revolution">
        introduced new irrigation
       </a>
       , some fruits and cotton, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Siculo-Arabic" title="Siculo-Arabic">
        Siculo-Arabic
       </a>
       language was adopted on the island from Sicily; it would eventually evolve into the
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">
        Maltese language
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
        <a href="#cite_note-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Christians on the island were allowed
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">
        freedom of religion
       </a>
       ; they had to pay
       <a href="/wiki/Jizya" title="Jizya">
        jizya
       </a>
       , a tax for non-Muslims, but were exempt from the tax that Muslims had to pay (
       <a href="/wiki/Zakat" title="Zakat">
        zakat
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gozmalt_74-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-gozmalt-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Norman_conquest">
        Norman conquest
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Norman conquest">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Roger_I_of_Sicily.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="250" data-file-width="193" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Roger_I_of_Sicily.jpg/170px-Roger_I_of_Sicily.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ea/Roger_I_of_Sicily.jpg 1.5x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Roger_I_of_Sicily.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Roger_I_of_Sicily" title="Roger I of Sicily">
          Roger I of Sicily
         </a>
         returned Malta to Christian rule.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Normans" title="Normans">
        Normans
       </a>
       captured Malta in 1091, as part of their
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_Sicily" title="Norman conquest of Sicily">
        conquest of Sicily
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
        <a href="#cite_note-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Norman leader,
       <a href="/wiki/Roger_I_of_Sicily" title="Roger I of Sicily">
        Roger I of Sicily
       </a>
       , was welcomed by the native Christians.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The notion that Count Roger I reportedly tore off a portion of his checkered red-and-white banner and presented it to the
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_people" title="Maltese people">
        Maltese
       </a>
       in gratitude for having fought on his behalf, forming the basis of the modern
       <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Malta" title="Flag of Malta">
        flag of Malta
       </a>
       , is founded in myth.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_by_Piri_Reis.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="812" data-file-width="546" height="253" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Malta_by_Piri_Reis.jpg/170px-Malta_by_Piri_Reis.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Malta_by_Piri_Reis.jpg/255px-Malta_by_Piri_Reis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Malta_by_Piri_Reis.jpg/340px-Malta_by_Piri_Reis.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_by_Piri_Reis.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
          Ottoman
         </a>
         map of Malta, by
         <a href="/wiki/Piri_Reis" title="Piri Reis">
          Piri Reis
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Norman period was productive; Malta became part of the newly formed
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sicily" title="Kingdom of Sicily">
        Kingdom of Sicily
       </a>
       which also covered the island of Sicily and the southern half of the
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_Peninsula" title="Italian Peninsula">
        Italian Peninsula
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Catholic Church was reinstated as the state religion with Malta under the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Palermo" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Palermo">
        See of Palermo
       </a>
       , and some
       <a href="/wiki/Norman_architecture" title="Norman architecture">
        Norman architecture
       </a>
       sprung up around Malta especially in its ancient capital
       <a href="/wiki/Mdina" title="Mdina">
        Mdina
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Tancred,_King_of_Sicily" title="Tancred, King of Sicily">
        Tancred, King of Sicily
       </a>
       , the last Norman monarch, made Malta a
       <a href="/wiki/Fief" title="Fief">
        fief
       </a>
       of the kingdom and installed a
       <a href="/wiki/Count_of_Malta" title="Count of Malta">
        count of Malta
       </a>
       . As the islands were much desired due to their strategic importance, it was during this time the men of Malta were
       <a href="/wiki/Militarization" title="Militarization">
        militarised
       </a>
       to fend off capture attempts; early counts were skilled
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">
        Genoese
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Privateer" title="Privateer">
        privateers
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The kingdom passed on to the dynasty of
       <a href="/wiki/Hohenstaufen" title="Hohenstaufen">
        Hohenstaufen
       </a>
       from 1194 until 1266. During this period, when Frederick II of Hohenstaufen began to reorganise his Sicilian kingdom, Western culture and religion began to exert their influence more intensely.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
        <a href="#cite_note-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Malta formed part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">
        Holy Roman Empire
       </a>
       for 72 years. Malta was declared a county and a
       <a href="/wiki/Marquess" title="Marquess">
        marquisate
       </a>
       , but its trade was totally ruined. For a long time it remained solely a fortified
       <a href="/wiki/Garrison" title="Garrison">
        garrison
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A mass expulsion of Arabs occurred in 1224 and the entire Christian male population of
       <a href="/wiki/Celano" title="Celano">
        Celano
       </a>
       in Abruzzo was deported to Malta in the same year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-8">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1249
       <a href="/wiki/Frederick_II,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor">
        Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor
       </a>
       , decreed that all remaining Muslims be expelled from Malta
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or impelled to convert.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       For a brief period the kingdom passed to the
       <a href="/wiki/Capetian_House_of_Anjou" title="Capetian House of Anjou">
        Capetian House of Anjou
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but high taxes made the dynasty unpopular in Malta, due in part to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charles_I_of_Naples" title="Charles I of Naples">
        Charles of Anjou
       </a>
       's war against the Republic of Genoa, and the island of
       <a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">
        Gozo
       </a>
       was sacked in 1275.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-9">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A large revolt on Sicily known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_Vespers" title="Sicilian Vespers">
        Sicilian Vespers
       </a>
       followed these attacks, a revolt that saw the Peninsula separating into the Kingdom of Naples.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Crown_of_Aragon_rule_and_the_Knights_of_Malta">
        Crown of Aragon rule and the Knights of Malta
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Crown of Aragon rule and the Knights of Malta">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/County_of_Sicily" title="County of Sicily">
        County of Sicily
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sicily" title="Kingdom of Sicily">
        Kingdom of Sicily
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Aragon" title="Crown of Aragon">
        Crown of Aragon
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Malta_under_the_Order_of_Saint_John" title="History of Malta under the Order of Saint John">
        History of Malta under the Order of Saint John
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Siege_of_Malta" title="Great Siege of Malta">
        Great Siege of Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bandiera_del_Regno_di_Sicilia_4.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="612" data-file-width="897" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Bandiera_del_Regno_di_Sicilia_4.svg/220px-Bandiera_del_Regno_di_Sicilia_4.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Bandiera_del_Regno_di_Sicilia_4.svg/330px-Bandiera_del_Regno_di_Sicilia_4.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Bandiera_del_Regno_di_Sicilia_4.svg/440px-Bandiera_del_Regno_di_Sicilia_4.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bandiera_del_Regno_di_Sicilia_4.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Flag of the Aragonese
         <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sicily" title="Kingdom of Sicily">
          Kingdom of Sicily
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Malta was ruled by the
       <a href="/wiki/House_of_Barcelona" title="House of Barcelona">
        House of Barcelona
       </a>
       , an Aragonese dynasty from 1282 to 1409,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culturalheritage.gov.mt_83-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-culturalheritage.gov.mt-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with the Aragonese aiding the Maltese insurgents in the
       <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_Vespers" title="Sicilian Vespers">
        Sicilian Vespers
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Malta" title="Battle of Malta">
        a naval battle in Grand Harbour in 1283
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Relatives of the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Aragonese_monarchs" title="List of Aragonese monarchs">
        kings of Aragon
       </a>
       ruled the island until 1409, when it formally passed to the
       <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Aragon" title="Crown of Aragon">
        Crown of Aragon
       </a>
       . Early on in the Aragonese ascendancy, the sons of the monarchy received the title, "Count of Malta". During this time much of the local nobility was created. By 1397, however, the bearing of the title "Count of Malta" reverted to a feudal basis, with two families fighting over the distinction, which caused some conflict. This led the
       <a href="/wiki/Martin_I_of_Sicily" title="Martin I of Sicily">
        Martin I of Sicily
       </a>
       to abolish the title. Dispute over the title returned when the title was reinstated a few years later and the Maltese, led by the local nobility, rose up against Count Gonsalvo Monroy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-10">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Although they opposed the Count, the Maltese voiced their loyalty to the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_monarchs_of_Sicily" title="List of monarchs of Sicily">
        Sicilian Crown
       </a>
       , which so impressed
       <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_V_of_Aragon" title="Alfonso V of Aragon">
        Alfonso V of Aragon
       </a>
       that he did not punish the people for their rebellion. Instead, he promised never to grant the title to a third party, and incorporated it back into the crown. The city of
       <a href="/wiki/Mdina" title="Mdina">
        Mdina
       </a>
       was given the title of
       <i>
        Città Notabile
       </i>
       as a result of this sequence of events.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-11">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JPDV.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="400" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/JPDV.jpg/170px-JPDV.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/JPDV.jpg/255px-JPDV.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/JPDV.jpg/340px-JPDV.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JPDV.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Jean_Parisot_de_Valette" title="Jean Parisot de Valette">
          Jean Parisot de Valette
         </a>
         , the founder of
         <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">
          Valletta
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_Mdina_BW_2011-10-05_12-41-38.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2578" data-file-width="3388" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Malta_Mdina_BW_2011-10-05_12-41-38.JPG/170px-Malta_Mdina_BW_2011-10-05_12-41-38.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Malta_Mdina_BW_2011-10-05_12-41-38.JPG/255px-Malta_Mdina_BW_2011-10-05_12-41-38.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Malta_Mdina_BW_2011-10-05_12-41-38.JPG/340px-Malta_Mdina_BW_2011-10-05_12-41-38.JPG 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_Mdina_BW_2011-10-05_12-41-38.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/St._Paul%27s_Cathedral,_Mdina" title="St. Paul's Cathedral, Mdina">
          St. Paul's Cathedral, Mdina
         </a>
         built in the
         <a href="/wiki/Baroque_architecture" title="Baroque architecture">
          Baroque
         </a>
         style
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       On 23 March 1530,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Charles_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor">
        Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor
       </a>
       , gave the islands to the
       <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">
        Knights Hospitaller
       </a>
       under the leadership of Frenchman
       <a href="/wiki/Philippe_Villiers_de_L%27Isle-Adam" title="Philippe Villiers de L'Isle-Adam">
        Philippe Villiers de L'Isle-Adam
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Princes_and_Grand_Masters_of_the_Sovereign_Military_Order_of_Malta" title="List of Princes and Grand Masters of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta">
        Grand Master of the Order
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
        <a href="#cite_note-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_87-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in perpetual lease for which they had to pay an annual
       <a href="/wiki/Tribute_of_the_Maltese_Falcon" title="Tribute of the Maltese Falcon">
        tribute of one single Maltese Falcon
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated6_88-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated6-88">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-odonnel_89-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-odonnel-89">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-perez_90-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-perez-90">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-elpais_91-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-elpais-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tc1_92-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tc1-92">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tc2_93-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tc2-93">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abc_94-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-abc-94">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These knights, a military religious order now known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">
        Knights of Malta
       </a>
       , had been driven out of
       <a href="/wiki/Rhodes" title="Rhodes">
        Rhodes
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman Empire
       </a>
       in 1522.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
        <a href="#cite_note-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1551, the population of the island of
       <a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">
        Gozo
       </a>
       (around 5,000 people) were taken as slaves by
       <a href="/wiki/Barbary_pirates" title="Barbary pirates">
        Barbary pirates
       </a>
       and brought to the
       <a href="/wiki/Barbary_Coast" title="Barbary Coast">
        Barbary Coast
       </a>
       in present-day
       <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">
        Libya
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michelangelo_Caravaggio_021.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2173" data-file-width="3200" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Michelangelo_Caravaggio_021.jpg/220px-Michelangelo_Caravaggio_021.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Michelangelo_Caravaggio_021.jpg/330px-Michelangelo_Caravaggio_021.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Michelangelo_Caravaggio_021.jpg/440px-Michelangelo_Caravaggio_021.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michelangelo_Caravaggio_021.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Beheading_of_Saint_John_the_Baptist_(Caravaggio)" title="The Beheading of Saint John the Baptist (Caravaggio)">
           The Beheading of Saint John
          </a>
         </i>
         , by
         <a href="/wiki/Caravaggio" title="Caravaggio">
          Caravaggio
         </a>
         . Oil on canvas, 361 cm × 520 cm (142.13
         <a href="/wiki/Inch" title="Inch">
          in
         </a>
         × 204.72 in). Oratory of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._John%27s_Co-Cathedral" title="St. John's Co-Cathedral">
          Co-Cathedral
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The knights, led by Frenchman
       <a href="/wiki/Jean_Parisot_de_Valette" title="Jean Parisot de Valette">
        Jean Parisot de Valette
       </a>
       , Grand Master of the Order, withstood the
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Siege_of_Malta" title="Great Siege of Malta">
        Great Siege of Malta
       </a>
       by the Ottomans in 1565.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_87-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The knights, with the help of Spanish and Maltese forces, were victorious and repelled the attack. Speaking of the battle
       <a href="/wiki/Voltaire" title="Voltaire">
        Voltaire
       </a>
