      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanisation">
        Urbanisation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Urbanisation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Valletta,_Malta.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="437" data-file-width="640" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Valletta%2C_Malta.JPG/330px-Valletta%2C_Malta.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Valletta%2C_Malta.JPG/495px-Valletta%2C_Malta.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a6/Valletta%2C_Malta.JPG 2x" width="330"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Valletta,_Malta.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The main urban area of Malta.
         <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">
          Valletta
         </a>
         is the central peninsula.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">
        Eurostat
       </a>
       , Malta is composed of two
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Larger_urban_zones" title="Larger urban zones">
        larger urban zones
       </a>
       nominally referred to as "Valletta" (the main island of Malta) and "Gozo". According to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Demographia" title="Demographia">
        Demographia
       </a>
       , state is identified as urban area.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
        <a href="#cite_note-146">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Spatial_Planning_Observation_Network" title="European Spatial Planning Observation Network">
        European Spatial Planning Observation Network
       </a>
       , Malta is identified as functional urban area (FUA).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
        <a href="#cite_note-147">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to United Nations, about 95 per cent of the area of Malta is urban and the number grows every year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
        <a href="#cite_note-148">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Also, according to the results of ESPON and EU Commission studies, "
       <i>
        the whole territory of Malta constitutes a single urban region
       </i>
       ".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Occasionally in the media and official publications Malta is referred to as a
       <a href="/wiki/City-state" title="City-state">
        city-state
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
        <a href="#cite_note-151">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Also, the Maltese coat-of-arms bears a
       <a href="/wiki/Mural_crown" title="Mural crown">
        mural crown
       </a>
       described as "representing the fortifications of Malta and denoting a City State".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
        <a href="#cite_note-152">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Malta, with area of 316 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (122 sq mi) and population of 0.4 million, is one of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_population_density" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by population density">
        most densely populated
       </a>
       countries worldwide.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Economy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Malta" title="Economy of Malta">
        Economy of Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AIDAcara_Valetta.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/AIDAcara_Valetta.jpg/220px-AIDAcara_Valetta.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/AIDAcara_Valetta.jpg/330px-AIDAcara_Valetta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/AIDAcara_Valetta.jpg/440px-AIDAcara_Valetta.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:AIDAcara_Valetta.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Valletta's maritime industrial zone
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Malta is classified as an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Advanced_economy" title="Advanced economy">
        advanced economy
       </a>
       together with 32 other countries according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
        <a href="#cite_note-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Until 1800 Malta depended on cotton, tobacco and its shipyards for exports. Once under British control, they came to depend on
       <a href="/wiki/Malta_Dockyard" title="Malta Dockyard">
        Malta Dockyard
       </a>
       for support of the
       <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">
        Royal Navy
       </a>
       , especially during the
       <a href="/wiki/Crimean_War" title="Crimean War">
        Crimean War
       </a>
       of 1854. The military base benefited craftsmen and all those who served the military.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1869, the opening of the
       <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">
        Suez Canal
       </a>
       gave Malta's economy a great boost, as there was a massive increase in the shipping which entered the port. Ships stopping at Malta's docks for refuelling helped the
       <a href="/wiki/Entrep%C3%B4t" title="Entrepôt">
        Entrepôt
       </a>
       trade, which brought additional benefits to the island.
      </p>
      <p>
       However, towards the end of the 19th century the economy began declining, and by the 1940s Malta's economy was in serious crisis. One factor was the longer range of newer merchant ships that required less frequent refuelling stops.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mediterraneo_dolphin_show_1.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Mediterraneo_dolphin_show_1.JPG/220px-Mediterraneo_dolphin_show_1.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Mediterraneo_dolphin_show_1.JPG/330px-Mediterraneo_dolphin_show_1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Mediterraneo_dolphin_show_1.JPG/440px-Mediterraneo_dolphin_show_1.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mediterraneo_dolphin_show_1.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The dolphin show at Mediterraneo Marine Park. Tourism generates a significant part of the GDP of Malta.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Currently, Malta's major resources are
       <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">
        limestone
       </a>
       , a favourable geographic location and a productive labour force. Malta produces only about 20 per cent of its food needs, has limited freshwater supplies because of the drought in the summer and has no domestic energy sources, aside from the potential for solar energy from its plentiful sunlight. The economy is dependent on foreign trade (serving as a freight trans-shipment point), manufacturing (especially electronics and textiles) and tourism.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Films_shot_in_Malta" title="Films shot in Malta">
        Film production
       </a>
       is a growing contributor to the Maltese economy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
        <a href="#cite_note-154">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The first film was shot in Malta in 1925 (
       <i>
        Sons of the Sea
       </i>
       );
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
        <a href="#cite_note-155">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       over 100 feature films have been entirely or partially filmed in the country since then. Malta has served as a "double" for a wide variety of locations and historic periods including Ancient Greece, Ancient and Modern Rome, Iraq, the Middle East and many more.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
        <a href="#cite_note-156">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Maltese government introduced financial incentives for filmmakers in 2005.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
        <a href="#cite_note-157">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The current financial incentives to foreign productions as of 2015 stand at 25 per cent with an additional 2 per cent if Malta stands in as Malta; meaning a production can get up to 27 per cent back on their eligible spending incurred in Malta.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
        <a href="#cite_note-158">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eurozone.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="456" data-file-width="450" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/220px-Eurozone.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/330px-Eurozone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/440px-Eurozone.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eurozone.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Malta is part of a monetary union, the
         <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
          eurozone
         </a>
         (dark blue)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The government is investing heavily in education, including college.
      </p>
      <p>
       In preparation for Malta's membership in the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       , which it joined on 1 May 2004, it
       <a href="/wiki/Privatization" title="Privatization">
        privatised
       </a>
       some state-controlled firms and liberalised markets. For example, the government announced on 8 January 2007 that it was selling its 40 per cent stake in
       <a href="/wiki/MaltaPost" title="MaltaPost">
        MaltaPost
       </a>
       , to complete a privatisation process which has been ongoing for the past five years. In 2010, Malta managed to privatise telecommunications, postal services, shipyards and shipbuilding.
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta has a financial regulator, the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Malta_Financial_Services_Authority&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Malta Financial Services Authority (page does not exist)">
        Malta Financial Services Authority
       </a>
       (MFSA), with a strong business development mindset, and the country has been successful in attracting gaming businesses, aircraft and ship registration, credit-card issuing banking licences and also fund administration. Service providers to these industries, including fiduciary and trustee business, are a core part of the growth strategy of the island. Malta has made strong headway in implementing EU Financial Services Directives including UCITs IV and soon AIFMD. As a base for alternative asset managers who must comply with new directives, Malta has attracted a number of key players including IDS, Iconic Funds,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Apex_Fund_Services&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Apex Fund Services (page does not exist)">
        Apex Fund Services
       </a>
       and TMF/Customs House.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta and
       <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">
        Tunisia
       </a>
       are currently discussing the commercial exploitation of the continental shelf between their countries, particularly for petroleum exploration. These discussions are also undergoing between Malta and
       <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">
        Libya
       </a>
       for similar arrangements.
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta does not have a property tax. Its property market, especially around the harbour area, has been in constant boom, with the prices of apartments in some towns like St Julian's, Sliema and Gzira skyrocketing.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
        <a href="#cite_note-160">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">
        Eurostat
       </a>
       data, Maltese GDP per capita stood at
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_European_Union#Richest_and_poorest_NUTS_regions_(GDP_PPP_2010)" title="Economy of the European Union">
        88 per cent of the EU average
       </a>
       in 2015 with €21,000.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eurostat_2012_161-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_2012-161">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Banking_and_finance">
        Banking and finance
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Banking and finance">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_St._Julian%27s_(Triq_it-Torri_(Sliema))_03_ies.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="5616" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Malta_-_St._Julian%27s_%28Triq_it-Torri_%28Sliema%29%29_03_ies.jpg/220px-Malta_-_St._Julian%27s_%28Triq_it-Torri_%28Sliema%29%29_03_ies.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Malta_-_St._Julian%27s_%28Triq_it-Torri_%28Sliema%29%29_03_ies.jpg/330px-Malta_-_St._Julian%27s_%28Triq_it-Torri_%28Sliema%29%29_03_ies.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Malta_-_St._Julian%27s_%28Triq_it-Torri_%28Sliema%29%29_03_ies.jpg/440px-Malta_-_St._Julian%27s_%28Triq_it-Torri_%28Sliema%29%29_03_ies.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_St._Julian%27s_(Triq_it-Torri_(Sliema))_03_ies.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Portomaso_Business_Tower" title="Portomaso Business Tower">
          Portomaso Business Tower
         </a>
         , the tallest building in Malta
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The two largest commercial banks are
       <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Valletta" title="Bank of Valletta">
        Bank of Valletta
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/HSBC_Bank_Malta" title="HSBC Bank Malta">
        HSBC Bank Malta
       </a>
       , both of which can trace their origins back to the 19th century.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Malta" title="Central Bank of Malta">
        Central Bank of Malta
       </a>
       (Bank Ċentrali ta' Malta) has two key areas of responsibility: the formulation and implementation of monetary policy and the promotion of a sound and efficient financial system. It was established by the Central Bank of Malta Act on 17 April 1968. The Maltese government entered
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ERM_II" title="ERM II">
        ERM II
       </a>
       on 4 May 2005, and adopted the euro as the country's currency on 1 January 2008.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
        <a href="#cite_note-162">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       FinanceMalta is the quasi-governmental organisation tasked with marketing and educating business leaders in coming to Malta and runs seminars and events around the world highlighting the emerging strength of Malta as a jurisdiction for banking and finance and insurance.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
        <a href="#cite_note-163">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">
        Transport
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Transport">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Malta" title="Transport in Malta">
        Transport in Malta
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Malta_bus" title="Malta bus">
        Malta bus
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Malta_2.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1114" data-file-width="987" height="248" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Map_of_Malta_2.png/220px-Map_of_Malta_2.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Map_of_Malta_2.png/330px-Map_of_Malta_2.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Map_of_Malta_2.png/440px-Map_of_Malta_2.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Malta_2.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Principal highways
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Traffic in Malta
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Driving_on_the_left_or_right" title="Driving on the left or right">
        drives on the left
       </a>
       . Car ownership in Malta is exceedingly high, considering the very small size of the islands; it is the fourth-highest in the European Union. The number of registered cars in 1990 amounted to 182,254, giving an automobile density of 577/km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (1,494/sq mi).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
        <a href="#cite_note-164">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta has 2,254 kilometres (1,401 miles) of road, 1,972 km (1,225 mi) (87.5 per cent) of which are paved and 282 km (175 mi) were unpaved (as of December 2003).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
        <a href="#cite_note-165">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The main roads of Malta from the southernmost point to the northernmost point are these: Triq Birżebbuġa in
       <a href="/wiki/Bir%C5%BCebbu%C4%A1a" title="Birżebbuġa">
        Birżebbuġa
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/G%C4%A7ar_Dalam" title="Għar Dalam">
        Għar Dalam
       </a>
       Road and
       <a href="/wiki/Tal-Barrani" title="Tal-Barrani">
        Tal-Barrani
       </a>
       Road in
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%BBejtun" title="Żejtun">
        Żejtun
       </a>
       , Santa Luċija Avenue in
       <a href="/wiki/Paola,_Malta" title="Paola, Malta">
        Paola
       </a>
       , Aldo Moro Street (Trunk Road), 13 December Street and
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%A6amrun" title="Ħamrun">
        Ħamrun
       </a>
       -Marsa Bypass in
       <a href="/wiki/Marsa,_Malta" title="Marsa, Malta">
        Marsa
       </a>
       , Regional Road in
       <a href="/wiki/Santa_Venera" title="Santa Venera">
        Santa Venera
       </a>
       /
       <a href="/wiki/Msida" title="Msida">
        Msida
       </a>
       /
       <a href="/wiki/G%C5%BCira" title="Gżira">
        Gżira
       </a>
       /
       <a href="/wiki/San_%C4%A0wann" title="San Ġwann">
        San Ġwann
       </a>
       , St Andrew's Road in
       <a href="/wiki/Swieqi" title="Swieqi">
        Swieqi
       </a>
       /
       <a href="/wiki/Pembroke,_Malta" title="Pembroke, Malta">
        Pembroke, Malta
       </a>
       , Coast Road in
       <a href="/wiki/Ba%C4%A7ar_i%C4%8B-%C4%8Aag%C4%A7aq" title="Baħar iċ-Ċagħaq">
        Baħar iċ-Ċagħaq
       </a>
       , Salina Road, Kennedy Drive, St. Paul's Bypass and
       <a href="/wiki/Xemxija" title="Xemxija">
        Xemxija
       </a>
       Hill in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/San_Pawl_il-Ba%C4%A7ar" title="San Pawl il-Baħar">
        San Pawl il-Baħar
       </a>
       , Mistra Hill, Wettinger Street (Mellieħa Bypass) and Marfa Road in
       <a href="/wiki/Mellie%C4%A7a" title="Mellieħa">
        Mellieħa
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_Busse_2016.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1125" data-file-width="1500" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Malta_Busse_2016.jpg/220px-Malta_Busse_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Malta_Busse_2016.jpg/330px-Malta_Busse_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Malta_Busse_2016.jpg/440px-Malta_Busse_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_Busse_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Maltese
         <i>
          Otokar
         </i>
         buses
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Malta_bus" title="Malta bus">
        Buses
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        xarabank
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        karozza tal-linja
       </i>
       ) are the primary method of public transport. Established in 1905, they operated in the Maltese islands up to 2011 and became popular tourist attractions in their own right.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
        <a href="#cite_note-166">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       To this day they are depicted on many Maltese advertisements to promote tourism as well as on gifts and merchandise for tourists.
      </p>
      <p>
       The bus service underwent an extensive reform in July 2011. The management structure changed from having self-employed drivers driving their own vehicles to a service being offered by a single company through a public tender (in Gozo, being considered as a small network, the service was given through direct order).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
        <a href="#cite_note-167">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The public tender was won by Arriva Malta, a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/Arriva" title="Arriva">
        Arriva
       </a>
       group, which introduced a fleet of brand new buses, built by
       <a href="/wiki/King_Long" title="King Long">
        King Long
       </a>
       especially for service by Arriva Malta and including a smaller fleet of
       <a href="/wiki/Articulated_bus" title="Articulated bus">
        articulated buses
       </a>
       brought in from
       <a href="/wiki/Arriva_London" title="Arriva London">
        Arriva London
       </a>
       . It also operated two smaller buses for an intra-
       <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">
        Valletta
       </a>
       route only and 61 nine-metre buses, which were used to ease congestion on high density routes. Overall Arriva Malta operated 264 buses. On 1 January 2014 Arriva ceased operations in Malta due to financial difficulties, having been nationalised as
       <i>
        Malta Public Transport
       </i>
       by the Maltese government, with a new bus operator planned to take over their operations in the near future.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
        <a href="#cite_note-169">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The government chose Autobuses Urbanos de León as its preferred bus operator for the country in October 2014.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
        <a href="#cite_note-170">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The company took over the bus service on 8 January 2015, while retaining the name
       <i>
        Malta Public Transport
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It introduced the pre-pay 'tallinja card'. With lower fares than the walk-on rate, it can be topped up online. The card was initially not well received, as reported by several local news sites.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the first week of August 2015, another 40 buses of the Turkish make
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Otokar" title="Otokar">
         Otokar
        </a>
       </i>
       arrived and were put into service.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
        <a href="#cite_note-173">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From 1883 to 1931 Malta had a railway line that connected
       <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">
        Valletta
       </a>
       to the army barracks at
       <a href="/wiki/Mtarfa" title="Mtarfa">
        Mtarfa
       </a>
       via
       <a href="/wiki/Mdina" title="Mdina">
        Mdina
       </a>
       and a number of towns and villages. The railway fell into disuse and eventually closed altogether, following the introduction of electric trams and buses.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
        <a href="#cite_note-174">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At the height of the bombing of Malta during the Second World War,
       <a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">
        Mussolini
       </a>
       announced that his forces had destroyed the railway system, but by the time war broke out, the railway had been mothballed for more than nine years.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Valletta-Harbour.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="527" data-file-width="1200" height="97" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Valletta-Harbour.jpg/220px-Valletta-Harbour.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Valletta-Harbour.jpg/330px-Valletta-Harbour.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Valletta-Harbour.jpg/440px-Valletta-Harbour.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Valletta-Harbour.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Grand_Harbour" title="Grand Harbour">
          Grand Harbour
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_Freeport_from_Pretty_Bay_at_Birzebbuga.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="960" data-file-width="1280" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Malta_Freeport_from_Pretty_Bay_at_Birzebbuga.jpg/220px-Malta_Freeport_from_Pretty_Bay_at_Birzebbuga.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Malta_Freeport_from_Pretty_Bay_at_Birzebbuga.jpg/330px-Malta_Freeport_from_Pretty_Bay_at_Birzebbuga.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Malta_Freeport_from_Pretty_Bay_at_Birzebbuga.jpg/440px-Malta_Freeport_from_Pretty_Bay_at_Birzebbuga.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_Freeport_from_Pretty_Bay_at_Birzebbuga.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Malta_Freeport" title="Malta Freeport">
          Malta Freeport
         </a>
         , one of the largest European ports
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Malta has three large natural harbours on its main island:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Grand_Harbour" title="Grand Harbour">
         Grand Harbour
        </a>
        (or Port il-Kbir), located at the eastern side of the capital city of
        <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">
         Valletta
        </a>
        , has been a harbour since
        <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
         Roman
        </a>
        times. It has several extensive
        <a href="/wiki/Dock_(maritime)" title="Dock (maritime)">
         docks
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Wharf" title="Wharf">
         wharves
        </a>
        , as well as a cruise liner terminal. A terminal at the Grand Harbour serves
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ferries" title="Ferries">
         ferries
        </a>
        that connect Malta to
        <a href="/wiki/Pozzallo" title="Pozzallo">
         Pozzallo
        </a>
        &amp;
        <a href="/wiki/Catania" title="Catania">
         Catania
        </a>
        in Sicily.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Marsamxett_Harbour" title="Marsamxett Harbour">
         Marsamxett Harbour
        </a>
        , located on the western side of Valletta, accommodates a number of yacht marinas.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marsaxlokk_Harbour" title="Marsaxlokk Harbour">
         Marsaxlokk Harbour
        </a>
        (Malta Freeport), at
        <a href="/wiki/Bir%C5%BCebbu%C4%A1a" title="Birżebbuġa">
         Birżebbuġa
        </a>
        on the south-eastern side of Malta, is the islands' main cargo terminal. Malta Freeport is the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_world%27s_busiest_container_ports" title="List of world's busiest container ports">
         11th busiest container ports in continent of Europe and 46th in the World
        </a>
        with a trade volume of 2.3 million
        <a href="/wiki/Twenty-foot_equivalent_unit" title="Twenty-foot equivalent unit">
         TEU's
        </a>
        in 2008.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
         <a href="#cite_note-175">
          [175]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       There are also two-man-made harbours that serve a passenger and car ferry service that connects
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%8Airkewwa" title="Ċirkewwa">
        Ċirkewwa
       </a>
       Harbour on Malta and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M%C4%A1arr_(Gozo)" title="Mġarr (Gozo)">
        Mġarr Harbour
       </a>
       on
       <a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">
        Gozo
       </a>
       . The ferry makes numerous runs each day.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_International_Airport2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Malta_International_Airport2.jpg/220px-Malta_International_Airport2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Malta_International_Airport2.jpg/330px-Malta_International_Airport2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Malta_International_Airport2.jpg/440px-Malta_International_Airport2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_International_Airport2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Malta_International_Airport" title="Malta International Airport">
          Malta International Airport
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Malta_International_Airport" title="Malta International Airport">
        Malta International Airport
       </a>
       (Ajruport Internazzjonali ta' Malta) is the only airport serving the Maltese islands. It is built on the land formerly occupied by the
       <a href="/wiki/RAF_Luqa" title="RAF Luqa">
        RAF Luqa
       </a>
       air base. A heliport is also located there, but the scheduled service to Gozo ceased in 2006. The heliport in Gozo is at
       <a href="/wiki/Xewkija" title="Xewkija">
        Xewkija
       </a>
       . Since June 2007,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Harbour_Air_Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Harbour Air Malta (page does not exist)">
        Harbour Air Malta
       </a>
       has operated a thrice-daily floatplane service between the sea terminal in Grand Harbour and Mgarr Harbour in Gozo.
      </p>
      <p>
       Two further airfields at
       <a href="/wiki/Ta%27_Qali" title="Ta' Qali">
        Ta' Qali
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%A6al_Far" title="Ħal Far">
        Ħal Far
       </a>
       operated during the Second World War and into the 1960s but are now closed. Today,
       <a href="/wiki/Ta%27_Qali" title="Ta' Qali">
        Ta' Qali
       </a>
       houses a national park,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ta%27_Qali_Stadium" title="Ta' Qali Stadium">
        stadium
       </a>
       , the Crafts Village visitor attraction and the
       <a href="/wiki/Malta_Aviation_Museum" title="Malta Aviation Museum">
        Malta Aviation Museum
       </a>
       . This museum preserves several aircraft, including
       <a href="/wiki/Hawker_Hurricane" title="Hawker Hurricane">
        Hurricane
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spitfire" title="Spitfire">
        Spitfire
       </a>
       fighters that defended the island in the Second World War.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Air_Malta_A319_9H-AEG.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2217" data-file-width="3326" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Air_Malta_A319_9H-AEG.JPG/220px-Air_Malta_A319_9H-AEG.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Air_Malta_A319_9H-AEG.JPG/330px-Air_Malta_A319_9H-AEG.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Air_Malta_A319_9H-AEG.JPG/440px-Air_Malta_A319_9H-AEG.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Air_Malta_A319_9H-AEG.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         An
         <a href="/wiki/Air_Malta" title="Air Malta">
          Air Malta
         </a>
         Airbus A319
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The national airline is
       <a href="/wiki/Air_Malta" title="Air Malta">
        Air Malta
       </a>
       , which is based at Malta International Airport and operates services to 36 destinations in Europe and North Africa. The owners of Air Malta are the
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Malta" title="Government of Malta">
        Government of Malta
       </a>
       (98 per cent) and private investors (2 percent). Air Malta employs 1,547 staff. It has a 25 per cent shareholding in
       <a href="/wiki/Medavia" title="Medavia">
        Medavia
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Air Malta has concluded over 191 interline ticketing agreements with other IATA airlines. It also has a codeshare agreement with
       <a href="/wiki/Qantas" title="Qantas">
        Qantas
       </a>
       covering three routes. In September 2007, Air Malta made two agreements with Abu Dhabi-based Etihad Airways by which Air Malta wet-leased two Airbus aircraft to
       <a href="/wiki/Etihad_Airways" title="Etihad Airways">
        Etihad Airways
       </a>
       for the winter period starting 1 September 2007, and provided operational support on another Airbus A320 aircraft which it leased to Etihad Airways.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Communications">
        Communications
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Communications">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The mobile penetration rate in Malta exceeded 100% by the end of 2009.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
        <a href="#cite_note-176">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Malta uses the
       <a href="/wiki/GSM" title="GSM">
        GSM
       </a>
       900, UMTS(3G) and LTE(4G) mobile phone systems, which are compatible with the rest of the European countries, Australia and New Zealand.
      </p>
      <p>
       Telephone and cellular subscribers' numbers have eight digits. There are no
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code" title="Area code">
        area codes
       </a>
       in Malta, but after inception, the original first two numbers, and currently the 3rd and 4th digit, were assigned according to the locality.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fixed_line" title="Fixed line">
        Fixed line
       </a>
       telephone numbers have the prefix 21 and 27, although businesses may have numbers starting 22 or 23. An example would be 2*80**** if from
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%BBabbar" title="Żabbar">
        Żabbar
       </a>
       , and 2*23**** if from
       <a href="/wiki/Marsa,_Malta" title="Marsa, Malta">
        Marsa
       </a>
       . Gozitan landline numbers generally are assigned 2*56****. Mobile telephone numbers have the prefix 77, 79, 98 or 99. When calling Malta from abroad, one must first dial the international access code, then the country code +356 and the subscriber's number.
      </p>
      <p>
       The number of pay TV subscribers fell as customers switched to
       <a href="/wiki/IPTV" title="IPTV">
        Internet Protocol television
       </a>
       (IPTV): the number of IPTV subscribers doubled in the six months to June 2012.
      </p>
      <p>
       In late 2012,
       <a href="/wiki/GO_(Malta)" title="GO (Malta)">
        GO
       </a>
       began expanding its fibre-to-the-home (FTTH) network and capabilities, offering speeds of up to 200Mbit/s for its 'rapido' service.
      </p>
      <p>
       In early 2012, the government called for a national FttH network to be built, with a minimum broadband service being upgraded from 4Mbit/s to 100Mbit/s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
        <a href="#cite_note-177">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Currency">
        Currency
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Currency">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_euro_coins" title="Maltese euro coins">
        Maltese euro coins
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Euro_gold_and_silver_commemorative_coins_(Malta)" title="Euro gold and silver commemorative coins (Malta)">
        Euro gold and silver commemorative coins (Malta)
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_euro_coins" title="Maltese euro coins">
        Maltese euro coins
       </a>
       feature the
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_cross" title="Maltese cross">
        Maltese cross
       </a>
       on €2 and €1 coins, the
       <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Malta" title="Coat of arms of Malta">
        coat of arms of Malta
       </a>
       on the €0.50, €0.20 and €0.10 coins, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Mnajdra" title="Mnajdra">
        Mnajdra
       </a>
       Temples on the €0.05, €0.02 and €0.01 coins.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
        <a href="#cite_note-178">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta has produced collectors' coins with face value ranging from 10 to 50 euro. These coins continue an existing national practice of minting of silver and gold commemorative coins. Unlike normal issues, these coins are not legal tender in all the eurozone. For instance, a €10 Maltese commemorative coin cannot be used in any other country.
      </p>
      <p>
       From 1972 until introduction of the Euro in 2008, the currency was the
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_lira" title="Maltese lira">
        Maltese lira
       </a>
       , which had replaced the Maltese pound. The pound replaced the
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_scudo" title="Maltese scudo">
        Maltese scudo
       </a>
       in 1825.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">
        Tourism
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Tourism">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mellieha_Bay_beach_Malta_1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1667" data-file-width="3000" height="122" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Mellieha_Bay_beach_Malta_1.jpg/220px-Mellieha_Bay_beach_Malta_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Mellieha_Bay_beach_Malta_1.jpg/330px-Mellieha_Bay_beach_Malta_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Mellieha_Bay_beach_Malta_1.jpg/440px-Mellieha_Bay_beach_Malta_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mellieha_Bay_beach_Malta_1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Mellieħa Bay beach
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Malta" title="Tourism in Malta">
        Tourism in Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Malta is a popular tourist destination, with 1.6 million tourists per year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
        <a href="#cite_note-179">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Three times more tourists visit than there are residents. Tourism infrastructure has increased dramatically over the years and a number of hotels are present on the island, although overdevelopment and the destruction of traditional housing is of growing concern. An increasing number of Maltese now travel abroad on holiday.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
        <a href="#cite_note-180">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In recent years, Malta has advertised itself as a
       <a href="/wiki/Medical_tourism" title="Medical tourism">
        medical tourism
       </a>
       destination,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
        <a href="#cite_note-181">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and a number of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Health_tourism_provider" title="Health tourism provider">
        health tourism providers
       </a>
       are developing the industry. However, no Maltese hospital has undergone independent
       <a href="/wiki/International_healthcare_accreditation" title="International healthcare accreditation">
        international healthcare accreditation
       </a>
       . Malta is popular with British medical tourists,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
        <a href="#cite_note-182">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
       pointing Maltese hospitals towards seeking UK-sourced accreditation, such as with the
       <a href="/wiki/Trent_Accreditation_Scheme" title="Trent Accreditation Scheme">
        Trent Accreditation Scheme
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">
        Science and technology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Science and technology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Malta signed a co-operation agreement with the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">
        European Space Agency
       </a>
       (ESA) for more-intensive co-operation in ESA projects.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Malta_signs_Cooperation_Agreement_with_ESA_183-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Malta_signs_Cooperation_Agreement_with_ESA-183">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Malta Council for Science and Technology (MCST) is the civil body responsible for the development of science and technology on an educational and social level. Most science students in Malta graduate from the University of Malta and are represented by S-Cubed (Science Student's Society), UESA (University Engineering Students Association) and ICTSA (University of Malta ICT Students' Association).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
        <a href="#cite_note-184">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
        <a href="#cite_note-185">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Demographics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Malta" title="Demographics of Malta">
        Demographics of Malta
       </a>
      </div>

        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +26.6%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1957
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         319,620
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +4.5%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1967
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         314,216
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         −1.7%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1985
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         345,418
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +9.9%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         1995
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         378,132
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         +9.5%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         2005
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         404,962
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +7.1%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         2010
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         417,432
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +3.1%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left">
         Source:
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census_186-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-census-186">
           [186]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Malta conducts a census of population and housing every ten years. The census held in November 2005 counted an estimated 96 per cent of the population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
        <a href="#cite_note-187">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A preliminary report was issued in April 2006 and the results were weighted to estimate for 100 per cent of the population.
      </p>
      <p>
       Native
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_people" title="Maltese people">
        Maltese people
       </a>
       make up the majority of the island. However, there are minorities, the largest of which are
       <a href="/wiki/British_people" title="British people">
        Britons
       </a>
       , many of whom are retirees. The population of Malta as of July 2011
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       was estimated at 408,000.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_22-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-cia-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2005
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , 17 per cent were aged 14 and under, 68 per cent were within the 15–64 age bracket whilst the remaining 13 per cent were 65 years and over. Malta's population density of 1,282 per square km (3,322/sq mi) is by far the highest in the EU and one of the highest in the world. By comparison, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_population_density" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by population density">
        average population density
       </a>
       for the "World (land only, excluding
       <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">
        Antarctica
       </a>
       )" was 54 pop./km² as of July 2014.
      </p>
      <p>
       The only census year showing a fall in population was that of 1967, with a 1.7 per cent total decrease, attributable to a substantial number of Maltese residents who emigrated.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census2005_188-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Census2005-188">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Maltese-resident population for 2004 was estimated to make up 97.0 per cent of the total resident population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Demo2004_189-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Demo2004-189">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       All censuses since 1842 have shown a slight excess of females over males. The 1901 and 1911 censuses came closest to recording a balance. The highest female-to-male ratio was reached in 1957 (1088:1000) but since then the ratio has dropped continuously. The 2005 census showed a 1013:1000 female-to-male ratio. Population growth has slowed down, from +9.5 per cent between the 1985 and 1995 censuses, to +6.9 per cent between the 1995 and 2005 censuses (a yearly average of +0.7 per cent). The birth rate stood at 3860 (a decrease of 21.8 per cent from the 1995 census) and the death rate stood at 3025. Thus, there was a natural population increase of 835 (compared to +888 for 2004, of which over a hundred were foreign residents).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NSO_20060711_190-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NSO_20060711-190">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Valletta.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Valletta.jpg/220px-Valletta.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Valletta.jpg/330px-Valletta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Valletta.jpg/440px-Valletta.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Valletta.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">
          Valletta
         </a>
         , Malta's capital city
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The population's age composition is similar to the age structure prevalent in the EU. Since 1967 there was observed a trend indicating an ageing population, and is expected to continue in the foreseeable future. Malta's
       <a href="/wiki/Dependency_ratio" title="Dependency ratio">
        old-age-dependency-ratio
       </a>
       rose from 17.2 per cent in 1995 to 19.8 per cent in 2005, reasonably lower than the EU's 24.9 per cent average; 31.5 per cent of the Maltese population is aged under 25 (compared to the EU's 29.1 per cent); but the 50–64 age group constitutes 20.3 per cent of the population, significantly higher than the EU's 17.9 per cent. Malta's old-age-dependency-ratio is expected to continue rising steadily in the coming years.
      </p>
      <p>
       Maltese legislation recognises both civil and canonical (ecclesiastical) marriages. Annulments by the ecclesiastical and civil courts are unrelated and are not necessarily mutually endorsed. Malta voted in favour of divorce legislation in a referendum held on 28 May 2011.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Abortion in Malta is illegal. A person must be 16 to marry.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">
        <a href="#cite_note-192">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The number of brides aged under 25 decreased from 1471 in 1997 to 766 in 2005; while the number of grooms under 25 decreased from 823 to 311. There is a constant trend that females are more likely than males to marry young. In 2005 there were 51 brides aged between 16 and 19, compared to 8 grooms.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NSO_20060711_190-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-NSO_20060711-190">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       At the end of 2007 the population of the Maltese Islands stood at 410,290 and is expected to reach 424,028 by 2025. At the moment,
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
          <span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (September 2015)">
           when?
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       females slightly outnumber males, making up 50.3 per cent of the population. The largest proportion of persons – 7.5 per cent – were aged 25–29, while there were 7.3 per cent falling into each of the 45–49 and 55–59 age brackets.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
        <a href="#cite_note-193">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">
        total fertility rate
       </a>
       (TFR) as of 2013
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       was estimated at 1.53 children born/woman, which is below the replacement rate of 2.1.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia.gov_194-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-194">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2012, 25.8 per cent of births were to unmarried women.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
        <a href="#cite_note-195">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">
        life expectancy
       </a>
       in 2013 was estimated at 79.98 years (77.69 years male, 82.41 years female).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia.gov_194-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-194">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
        Languages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Languages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Il-Kantilena.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="680" height="324" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Il-Kantilena.png/220px-Il-Kantilena.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Il-Kantilena.png/330px-Il-Kantilena.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Il-Kantilena.png/440px-Il-Kantilena.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Il-Kantilena.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Il-Kantilena" title="Il-Kantilena">
           Il-Kantilena
          </a>
         </i>
         by
         <a href="/wiki/Pietru_Caxaro" title="Pietru Caxaro">
          Pietru Caxaro
         </a>
         , the oldest text in
         <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">
          Maltese language
         </a>
         , 15th century
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Malta" title="Languages of Malta">
        Languages of Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="#Education">
        § Education
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">
        Maltese language
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">
        Maltese
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="mt">
         Malti
        </span>
       </i>
       ) is the constitutional
       <a href="/wiki/National_language" title="National language">
        national language
       </a>
       of Malta, having become official, however, only in 1934. Previously,
       <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_language" title="Sicilian language">
        Sicilian
       </a>
       was the official and cultural language of Malta from the 12th century, and
       <a href="/wiki/Tuscan_dialect" title="Tuscan dialect">
        Tuscan dialect
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
        Italian
       </a>
       from the 16th century. Alongside Maltese, English is also an official language of the country and hence the laws of the land are enacted both in Maltese and English. However, the Constitution states that if there is any conflict between the Maltese and the English texts of any law, the Maltese text shall prevail.
      </p>
      <p>
       Maltese is a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semitic_language" title="Semitic language">
        Semitic language
       </a>
       descended from the now defunct Sicilian-Arabic (
       <a href="/wiki/Siculo-Arabic" title="Siculo-Arabic">
        Siculo-Arabic
       </a>
       ) dialect (from
       <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">
        southern Italy
       </a>
       ) that developed during the
       <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Sicily" title="Emirate of Sicily">
        Emirate of Sicily
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MED_196-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MED-196">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_alphabet" title="Maltese alphabet">
        Maltese alphabet
       </a>
       consists of 30 letters based on the
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">
        Latin alphabet
       </a>
       , including the
       <a href="/wiki/Diacritic" title="Diacritic">
        diacritically
       </a>
       altered letters
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/%C5%BB" title="Ż">
         ż
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/%C4%8A" title="Ċ">
         ċ
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/%C4%A0" title="Ġ">
         ġ
        </a>
       </i>
       , as well as the letters
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G%C4%A7" title="Għ">
         għ
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%A6" title="Ħ">
         ħ
        </a>
       </i>
       , and
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ie_(digraph)" title="Ie (digraph)">
         ie
        </a>
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Maltese has a Semitic base with substantial borrowing from
       <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_language" title="Sicilian language">
        Sicilian
       </a>
       , Italian, a little French, and more recently and increasingly, English.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
        <a href="#cite_note-197">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The hybrid character of Maltese was established by a long period of Maltese-Sicilian urban bilingualism gradually transforming rural speech and which ended in the early 19th century with Maltese emerging as the vernacular of the entire native population. The language includes different dialects that can vary greatly from one town to another or from one island to another.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">
        Eurobarometer
       </a>
       states that 100 per cent of the population speak Maltese. Also, 88 per cent of the population speak English, 66 per cent speak Italian, and 17 per cent speak French.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
        <a href="#cite_note-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This widespread knowledge of
       <a href="/wiki/Second_language" title="Second language">
        second languages
       </a>
       makes Malta one of the most multilingual countries in the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       . A study collecting public opinion on what language was "preferred" discovered that 86 per cent of the population express a preference for Maltese, 12 per cent for English, and 2 per cent for Italian.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LinguisticView_199-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LinguisticView-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Still, Italian television channels from Italy-based broadcasters, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Mediaset" title="Mediaset">
        Mediaset
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/RAI" title="RAI">
        RAI
       </a>
       , reach Malta and remain popular.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LinguisticView_199-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-LinguisticView-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
        <a href="#cite_note-200">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
        <a href="#cite_note-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Largest_cities">
        Largest cities
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>

         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Malta" title="List of cities in Malta">
        List of cities in Malta
       </a>
      </div>

         </a>
        </th>

         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_towns_in_Malta_and_Gozo" title="List of towns in Malta and Gozo">

         </a>
        </th>
        <th>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Birkirkara-residencial-area.jpg" title="Birkirkara">
          <img alt="Birkirkara" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2100" data-file-width="5000" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Birkirkara-residencial-area.jpg/120px-Birkirkara-residencial-area.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Birkirkara-residencial-area.jpg/180px-Birkirkara-residencial-area.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Birkirkara-residencial-area.jpg/240px-Birkirkara-residencial-area.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a href="/wiki/Birkirkara" title="Birkirkara">
          Birkirkara
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_St._Paul%27s_Bay_-_Bay%2BTriq_San_Pawl_(Xatt_il-Pwales)_03_ies.jpg" title="Saint Paul's Bay">
          <img alt="Saint Paul's Bay" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="5616" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Malta_-_St._Paul%27s_Bay_-_Bay%2BTriq_San_Pawl_%28Xatt_il-Pwales%29_03_ies.jpg/120px-Malta_-_St._Paul%27s_Bay_-_Bay%2BTriq_San_Pawl_%28Xatt_il-Pwales%29_03_ies.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Malta_-_St._Paul%27s_Bay_-_Bay%2BTriq_San_Pawl_%28Xatt_il-Pwales%29_03_ies.jpg/180px-Malta_-_St._Paul%27s_Bay_-_Bay%2BTriq_San_Pawl_%28Xatt_il-Pwales%29_03_ies.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Malta_-_St._Paul%27s_Bay_-_Bay%2BTriq_San_Pawl_%28Xatt_il-Pwales%29_03_ies.jpg/240px-Malta_-_St._Paul%27s_Bay_-_Bay%2BTriq_San_Pawl_%28Xatt_il-Pwales%29_03_ies.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a href="/wiki/St._Paul%27s_Bay" title="St. Paul's Bay">
          Saint Paul's Bay
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
         1
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Birkirkara" title="Birkirkara">
          Birkirkara
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Central_Region,_Malta" title="Central Region, Malta">
          Central
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">
         22,247
        </td>
        <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mosta_Dome_4_(6946839125).jpg" title="Mosta">
          <img alt="Mosta" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2892" data-file-width="5016" height="69" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Mosta_Dome_4_%286946839125%29.jpg/120px-Mosta_Dome_4_%286946839125%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Mosta_Dome_4_%286946839125%29.jpg/180px-Mosta_Dome_4_%286946839125%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Mosta_Dome_4_%286946839125%29.jpg/240px-Mosta_Dome_4_%286946839125%29.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a href="/wiki/Mosta" title="Mosta">
          Mosta
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sliema_in_the_afternoon.jpg" title="Sliema">
          <img alt="Sliema" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1602" data-file-width="2400" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sliema_in_the_afternoon.jpg/120px-Sliema_in_the_afternoon.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sliema_in_the_afternoon.jpg/180px-Sliema_in_the_afternoon.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sliema_in_the_afternoon.jpg/240px-Sliema_in_the_afternoon.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
         </a>

         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Religion">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Domen_i_Mosta.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1504" data-file-width="1754" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Domen_i_Mosta.jpg/220px-Domen_i_Mosta.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Domen_i_Mosta.jpg/330px-Domen_i_Mosta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Domen_i_Mosta.jpg/440px-Domen_i_Mosta.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Domen_i_Mosta.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Rotunda_of_Mosta" title="Rotunda of Mosta">
          Mosta Dome
         </a>
         known as "Ir-Rotunda"
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <table cellspacing="5" class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em; font-size: 85%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 40%;">
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align: left;">
         <i>
          (1) The religion of Malta is the Roman Catholic apostolic religion.
          <br/>
          (2) The authorities of the Roman Catholic apostolic church have the duty and the right to teach which principles are right and which are wrong.
          <br/>
          (3) Religious teaching of the Roman Catholic apostolic faith shall be provided in all state schools as part of compulsory education.
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align: left;">
         Chapter 1, Article 2 of the Constitution of Malta
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-legal-malta_23-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-legal-malta-23">
           [23]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="thumb tright" style="">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:200px">
        <div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black">
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:Gray">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 344.20225766694px; border-left-color:Orange">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Orange">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Orange">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 262.14865391968px; border-left-color:Green">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Green">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Green">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 171.54162365571px; border-left-color:Aqua">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Aqua">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Aqua">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 134.06260318686px; border-left-color:CornflowerBlue">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:CornflowerBlue">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:CornflowerBlue">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 120.87923504096px; border-left-color:MediumTurquoise">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:MediumTurquoise">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:MediumTurquoise">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 114.87477060345px; border-left-color:DodgerBlue">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:DodgerBlue">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:DodgerBlue">
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <p>
          Religion in Malta (2016)
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
           <a href="#cite_note-202">
            [202]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </p>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:DodgerBlue; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">
           Roman Catholicism
          </a>
          (88.6%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:MediumTurquoise; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">
           Jehovah's Witnesses
          </a>
          (0.4%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:CornflowerBlue; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Other Christian (0.8%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
