          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Aqua; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <abbr title="Believe in God without religion">
           Only believe in God
          </abbr>
          (1.8%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Green; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
           Islam
          </a>
          (2.6%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Orange; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Other religions (1.3%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Gray; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">
           Atheists
          </a>
          and
          <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">
           non-religious
          </a>
          (4.5%)
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Malta" title="Religion in Malta">
        Religion in Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Malta" title="History of the Jews in Malta">
        History of the Jews in Malta
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Malta" title="Christianity in Malta">
        Christianity in Malta
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Malta" title="Islam in Malta">
        Islam in Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The predominant religion in Malta is
       <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">
        Roman Catholicism
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Malta" title="Constitution of Malta">
        Constitution of Malta
       </a>
       establishes Catholicism as the
       <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">
        state religion
       </a>
       and it is also reflected in various elements of
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Malta" title="Culture of Malta">
        Maltese culture
       </a>
       , although
       <a href="/wiki/Entrenched_clause" title="Entrenched clause">
        entrenched provisions
       </a>
       for the freedom of religion are made.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-legal-malta_23-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-legal-malta-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are more than 360 churches in Malta, Gozo and Comino, or one church for every 1,000 residents. The parish church (Maltese:
       <i>
        "il-parroċċa"
       </i>
       , or
       <i>
        "il-knisja parrokkjali"
       </i>
       ) is the architectural and geographic focal point of every Maltese town and village, and its main source of civic pride. This civic pride manifests itself in spectacular fashion during the local village
       <i>
        festas
       </i>
       , which mark the day of the patron saint of each parish with marching bands, religious processions, special
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holy_Mass" title="Holy Mass">
        Masses
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fireworks" title="Fireworks">
        fireworks
       </a>
       (especially petards) and other festivities.
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta is an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apostolic_See" title="Apostolic See">
        Apostolic See
       </a>
       ; the
       <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">
        Acts of the Apostles
       </a>
       tells of how
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paul_of_Tarsus" title="Paul of Tarsus">
        St. Paul
       </a>
       , on his way from Jerusalem to Rome to face trial, was shipwrecked on the island of "Melite", which many Bible scholars identify with Malta, an episode dated around AD 60.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-doi.gov.mt_203-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-doi.gov.mt-203">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As recorded in the Acts of the Apostles, St. Paul spent three months on the island on his way to Rome, curing the sick including the father of Publius, the "chief man of the island". Various traditions are associated with this account. The shipwreck is said to have occurred in the place today known as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Bay" title="St Paul's Bay">
        St Paul's Bay
       </a>
       . The Maltese saint,
       <a href="/wiki/Saint_Publius" title="Saint Publius">
        Saint Publius
       </a>
       is said to have been made Malta's first bishop and a grotto in
       <a href="/wiki/Rabat,_Malta" title="Rabat, Malta">
        Rabat
       </a>
       , now known as "St Paul's Grotto" (and in the vicinity of which evidence of Christian burials and rituals from the 3rd century AD has been found), is among the earliest known places of Christian worship on the island.
      </p>
      <p>
       Further evidence of Christian practices and beliefs during the period of Roman persecution appears in
       <a href="/wiki/Catacombs" title="Catacombs">
        catacombs
       </a>
       that lie beneath various sites around Malta, including St Paul's Catacombs and St Agatha's Catacombs in Rabat, just outside the walls of
       <a href="/wiki/Mdina" title="Mdina">
        Mdina
       </a>
       . The latter, in particular, were beautifully frescoed between 1200 and 1480, although marauding
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Turks
       </a>
       defaced many of them in the 1550s. There are also a number of cave churches, including the grotto at
       <a href="/wiki/Sanctuary_of_Our_Lady_of_Mellie%C4%A7a" title="Sanctuary of Our Lady of Mellieħa">
        Mellieħa
       </a>
       , which is a Shrine of the Nativity of Our Lady where, according to legend,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Luke" title="St. Luke">
        St. Luke
       </a>
       painted a picture of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Madonna" title="The Madonna">
        Madonna
       </a>
       . It has been a place of pilgrimage since
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Medieval" title="Medieval">
        medieval
       </a>
       times.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Acts of the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">
        Council of Chalcedon
       </a>
       record that in 451 AD a certain Acacius was Bishop of Malta (
       <i>
        Melitenus Episcopus
       </i>
       ). It is also known that in 501 AD, a certain Constantinus,
       <i>
        Episcopus Melitenensis
       </i>
       , was present at the
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Council_of_Constantinople" title="Second Council of Constantinople">
        Fifth Ecumenical Council
       </a>
       . In 588 AD,
       <a href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_I" title="Pope Gregory I">
        Pope Gregory I
       </a>
       deposed Tucillus,
       <i>
        Miletinae civitatis episcopus
       </i>
       and the clergy and people of Malta elected his successor Trajan in 599 AD. The last recorded Bishop of Malta before the invasion of the islands was a Greek named Manas, who was subsequently incarcerated at
       <a href="/wiki/Palermo" title="Palermo">
        Palermo
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Maltese historian
       <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Francesco_Abela" title="Giovanni Francesco Abela">
        Giovanni Francesco Abela
       </a>
       states that following their conversion to Christianity at the hand of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saul_of_Tarsus" title="Saul of Tarsus">
        St. Paul
       </a>
       , the Maltese retained their Christian religion, despite the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fatimid" title="Fatimid">
        Fatimid
       </a>
       invasion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
        <a href="#cite_note-205">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Abela's writings describe Malta as a divinely ordained "bulwark of Christian, European civilization against the spread of Mediterranean Islam".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The native Christian community that welcomed
       <a href="/wiki/Roger_I_of_Sicily" title="Roger I of Sicily">
        Roger I of Sicily
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malticross_30-12">
        <a href="#cite_note-malticross-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       was further bolstered by immigration to Malta from Italy, in the 12th and 13th centuries.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ZTN_city_center.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="345" data-file-width="500" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/ZTN_city_center.jpg/220px-ZTN_city_center.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/ZTN_city_center.jpg/330px-ZTN_city_center.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/ZTN_city_center.jpg/440px-ZTN_city_center.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ZTN_city_center.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/%C5%BBejtun" title="Żejtun">
          Żejtun
         </a>
         city centre parish church
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       For centuries, the Church in Malta was subordinate to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Palermo" title="Diocese of Palermo">
        Diocese of Palermo
       </a>
       , except when it was under
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charles_of_Anjou" title="Charles of Anjou">
        Charles of Anjou
       </a>
       , who appointed bishops for Malta, as did – on rare occasions – the Spanish and later, the Knights. Since 1808 all bishops of Malta have been Maltese. As a result of the
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Malta#Kingdom_of_Sicily" title="History of Malta">
        Norman
       </a>
       and Spanish periods, and the rule of the Knights, Malta became the devout Catholic nation that it is today. It is worth noting that the Office of the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Inquisition" title="Roman Inquisition">
        Inquisitor of Malta
       </a>
       had a very long tenure on the island following its establishment in 1530: the last Inquisitor departed from the Islands in 1798, after the Knights capitulated to the forces of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Napoleon_Bonaparte" title="Napoleon Bonaparte">
        Napoleon Bonaparte
       </a>
       . During the period of the
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">
        Republic of Venice
       </a>
       , several Maltese families emigrated to
       <a href="/wiki/Corfu" title="Corfu">
        Corfu
       </a>
       . Their descendants account for about two-thirds of the community of some 4,000 Catholics that now live on that island.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Greek_Orthodox_Church_of_Saint_George_in_Valletta.jpeg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3328" data-file-width="2538" height="288" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Greek_Orthodox_Church_of_Saint_George_in_Valletta.jpeg/220px-Greek_Orthodox_Church_of_Saint_George_in_Valletta.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Greek_Orthodox_Church_of_Saint_George_in_Valletta.jpeg/330px-Greek_Orthodox_Church_of_Saint_George_in_Valletta.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Greek_Orthodox_Church_of_Saint_George_in_Valletta.jpeg/440px-Greek_Orthodox_Church_of_Saint_George_in_Valletta.jpeg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Greek_Orthodox_Church_of_Saint_George_in_Valletta.jpeg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Greek Orthodox church of St. Georg in Valletta
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The patron saints of Malta are
       <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">
        Saint Paul
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Saint_Publius" title="Saint Publius">
        Saint Publius
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Agatha_of_Sicily" title="Agatha of Sicily">
        Saint Agatha
       </a>
       . Although not a patron saint,
       <a href="/wiki/George_Preca" title="George Preca">
        St George Preca
       </a>
       (San Ġorġ Preca) is greatly revered as the second canonised Maltese saint after
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Publius" title="St. Publius">
        St. Publius
       </a>
       Malta's first acknowledged saint (canonised in the year 1634).
       <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">
        Pope Benedict XVI
       </a>
       canonised him on 3 June 2007. Also, a number of Maltese individuals are recognised as
       <a href="/wiki/Beatification" title="Beatification">
        Blessed
       </a>
       , including
       <a href="/wiki/Maria_Adeodata_Pisani" title="Maria Adeodata Pisani">
        Maria Adeodata Pisani
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nazju_Falzon" title="Nazju Falzon">
        Nazju Falzon
       </a>
       , with
       <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">
        Pope John Paul II
       </a>
       having
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beatified" title="Beatified">
        beatified
       </a>
       them in 2001.
      </p>
      <p>
       Various Roman Catholic religious orders are present in Malta, including the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesuits" title="Jesuits">
        Jesuits
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Franciscans" title="Franciscans">
        Franciscans
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Order" title="Dominican Order">
        Dominicans
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Little_Sisters_of_the_Poor" title="Little Sisters of the Poor">
        Little Sisters of the Poor
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Most congregants of the local
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">
        Protestant
       </a>
       churches are not Maltese; their congregations draw on the many British retirees living in the country and vacationers from many other nations. There are approximately 600
       <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">
        Jehovah's Witnesses
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
        <a href="#cite_note-207">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">
        The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
       </a>
       (LDS Church), the Bible Baptist Church, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Fellowship_of_Evangelical_Churches" title="Fellowship of Evangelical Churches">
        Fellowship of Evangelical Churches
       </a>
       each have about 60 affiliates. There are also some churches of other denominations, including
       <a href="/wiki/St._Andrew%27s_Scots_Church,_Malta" title="St. Andrew's Scots Church, Malta">
        St. Andrew's Scots Church
       </a>
       in Valletta (a joint
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presbyterian" title="Presbyterian">
        Presbyterian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Methodist_Church_of_Great_Britain" title="Methodist Church of Great Britain">
        Methodist
       </a>
       congregation) and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Anglican_Cathedral" title="St Paul's Anglican Cathedral">
        St Paul's Anglican Cathedral
       </a>
       , and a
       <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">
        Seventh-day Adventist
       </a>
       church in
       <a href="/wiki/Birkirkara" title="Birkirkara">
        Birkirkara
       </a>
       . A
       <a href="/wiki/New_Apostolic_Church" title="New Apostolic Church">
        New Apostolic Church
       </a>
       congregation was founded in 1983 in Gwardamangia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive.maltatoday.com.mt_208-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-archive.maltatoday.com.mt-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Jewish population of Malta reached its peak in the Middle Ages under Norman rule. In 1479, Malta and
       <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">
        Sicily
       </a>
       came under
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Aragon" title="Kingdom of Aragon">
        Aragonese
       </a>
       rule and the
       <a href="/wiki/Alhambra_Decree" title="Alhambra Decree">
        Alhambra Decree
       </a>
       of 1492 forced all Jews to leave the country, permitting them to take with them only a few of their belongings. Several dozen Maltese Jews may have
       <a href="/wiki/Religious_conversion" title="Religious conversion">
        converted
       </a>
       to Christianity at the time to remain in the country. Today, there is one Jewish congregation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive.maltatoday.com.mt_208-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-archive.maltatoday.com.mt-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_Paola_-_Triq_Kordin_-_Mosque_07_ies.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="5616" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Malta_-_Paola_-_Triq_Kordin_-_Mosque_07_ies.jpg/220px-Malta_-_Paola_-_Triq_Kordin_-_Mosque_07_ies.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Malta_-_Paola_-_Triq_Kordin_-_Mosque_07_ies.jpg/330px-Malta_-_Paola_-_Triq_Kordin_-_Mosque_07_ies.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Malta_-_Paola_-_Triq_Kordin_-_Mosque_07_ies.jpg/440px-Malta_-_Paola_-_Triq_Kordin_-_Mosque_07_ies.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_Paola_-_Triq_Kordin_-_Mosque_07_ies.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mariam_Al-Batool_Mosque" title="Mariam Al-Batool Mosque">
          Mariam Al-Batool Mosque
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Paola,_Malta" title="Paola, Malta">
          Paola, Malta
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       There is one Muslim mosque, the
       <a href="/wiki/Mariam_Al-Batool_Mosque" title="Mariam Al-Batool Mosque">
        Mariam Al-Batool Mosque
       </a>
       . A Muslim primary school recently opened. Of the estimated 3,000
       <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Malta" title="Islam in Malta">
        Muslims in Malta
       </a>
       , approximately 2,250 are foreigners, approximately 600 are naturalised citizens, and approximately 150 are native-born Maltese.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
        <a href="#cite_note-209">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zen_Buddhism" title="Zen Buddhism">
        Zen Buddhism
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá'í Faith">
        Bahá'í Faith
       </a>
       claim some 40 members.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive.maltatoday.com.mt_208-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-archive.maltatoday.com.mt-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In a survey held by the
       <a href="/wiki/Malta_Today" title="Malta Today">
        Malta Today
       </a>
       , it was found that approximately 4.5 per cent of the population of Malta gives no preference to any religious belief.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-religious" title="Non-religious">
        Non-religious
       </a>
       people have a higher risk to suffer from discrimination, such as lack of trust by society and unequal treatment by institutions. The number of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheists" title="Atheists">
        Atheists
       </a>
       has exponentially grown, by doubling from 2014 to 2016. According to European standards, non-religious groups and individuals are considered to suffer from "severe discrimination". By a constitutional amendment adhering to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EU_law" title="EU law">
        EU law
       </a>
       , Malta gives the right for the freedom to any religion or none at all but
       <i>
        de jure
       </i>
       not
       <i>
        de facto
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Migration">
        Migration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Migration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Inbound_migration">
        Inbound migration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Inbound migration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="toc" style="width:25%; float:right; text-align:center; clear:all; margin-left:8px; font-size:90%;">
       <tr>
        <th colspan="20" style="background:green; color:white;">
         Foreign population in Malta
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr style="background:#efefef;">
        <th width="15%">
         Year
        </th>
        <th width="60%">
         Population
        </th>
        <th width="25%">
         % total
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         2005
        </td>
        <td align="center">
         12,112
        </td>
        <td align="right">
         3.0%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         2011
        </td>
        <td align="center">
         20,289
        </td>
        <td align="right">
         4.9%
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Malta" title="Immigration to Malta">
        Immigration to Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Most of the foreign community in Malta, predominantly active or retired British nationals and their dependents, is centred on
       <a href="/wiki/Sliema" title="Sliema">
        Sliema
       </a>
       and surrounding modern suburbs. Other smaller foreign groups include Italians, French, and
       <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_people" title="Lebanese people">
        Lebanese
       </a>
       , many of whom have assimilated into the Maltese nation over the decades.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
        <a href="#cite_note-211">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Since the late 20th century, Malta has become a transit country for migration routes from Africa towards Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
        <a href="#cite_note-212">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       and of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Schengen_agreement" title="Schengen agreement">
        Schengen agreement
       </a>
       , Malta is bound by the
       <a href="/wiki/Dublin_Regulation" title="Dublin Regulation">
        Dublin Regulation
       </a>
       to process all claims for asylum by those asylum seekers that enter EU territory for the first time in Malta.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
        <a href="#cite_note-213">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Irregular migrants who land in Malta are subject to a
       <a href="/wiki/Immigration_detention" title="Immigration detention">
        compulsory detention policy
       </a>
       , being held in several camps organised by the
       <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Malta" title="Armed Forces of Malta">
        Armed Forces of Malta
       </a>
       (AFM), including those near
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%A6al_Far" title="Ħal Far">
        Ħal Far
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Safi,_Malta" title="Safi, Malta">
        Ħal Safi
       </a>
       . The compulsory detention policy has been denounced by several NGOs, and in July 2010, the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Human_Rights" title="European Court of Human Rights">
        European Court of Human Rights
       </a>
       found that Malta's detention of migrants was arbitrary, lacking in adequate procedures to challenge detention, and in breach of its obligations under the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights" title="European Convention on Human Rights">
        European Convention on Human Rights
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In January 2014 Malta started granting citizenship for a €650,000 contribution plus investments, contingent on residence and criminal background requirements.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
        <a href="#cite_note-216">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Outbound_migration">
        Outbound migration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Outbound migration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_Floriana_-_Valletta_Waterfront_-_Laguna_Marina_-_Child_Migrants%27_Memorial_03_ies.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="5616" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Malta_-_Floriana_-_Valletta_Waterfront_-_Laguna_Marina_-_Child_Migrants%27_Memorial_03_ies.jpg/220px-Malta_-_Floriana_-_Valletta_Waterfront_-_Laguna_Marina_-_Child_Migrants%27_Memorial_03_ies.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Malta_-_Floriana_-_Valletta_Waterfront_-_Laguna_Marina_-_Child_Migrants%27_Memorial_03_ies.jpg/330px-Malta_-_Floriana_-_Valletta_Waterfront_-_Laguna_Marina_-_Child_Migrants%27_Memorial_03_ies.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Malta_-_Floriana_-_Valletta_Waterfront_-_Laguna_Marina_-_Child_Migrants%27_Memorial_03_ies.jpg/440px-Malta_-_Floriana_-_Valletta_Waterfront_-_Laguna_Marina_-_Child_Migrants%27_Memorial_03_ies.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_Floriana_-_Valletta_Waterfront_-_Laguna_Marina_-_Child_Migrants%27_Memorial_03_ies.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Child Migrants' Memorial at the
         <a href="/wiki/Valletta_Waterfront" title="Valletta Waterfront">
          Valletta Waterfront
         </a>
         , commemorating the 310 child migrants who travelled to Australia between 1950 and 1965
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Emigration_from_Malta" title="Emigration from Malta">
        Emigration from Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       In the 19th century, most emigration from Malta was to North Africa and the Middle East, although rates of
       <a href="/wiki/Repatriation" title="Repatriation">
        return migration
       </a>
       to Malta were high.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jones_217-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Jones-217">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Nonetheless, Maltese communities formed in these regions. By 1900, for example, British consular estimates suggest that there were 15,326 Maltese in
       <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">
        Tunisia
       </a>
       , and in 1903 it was claimed that 15,000 people of Maltese origin were living in
       <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">
        Algeria
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Attard_218-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Attard-218">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta experienced significant emigration as a result of the collapse of a construction boom in 1907 and after the Second World War, when the
       <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">
        birth rate
       </a>
       increased significantly, but in the 20th century most emigrants went to destinations in the
       <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">
        New World
       </a>
       , particularly to Australia, Canada and the United States. After the Second World War, Malta's Emigration Department would assist emigrants with the cost of their travel. Between 1948 and 1967, 30 per cent of the population emigrated.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jones_217-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Jones-217">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Between 1946 and the late-1970s, over 140,000 people left Malta on the assisted passage scheme, with 57.6% migrating to Australia, 22% to the UK, 13% to Canada and 7% to the United States.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-King_219-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-King-219">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Emigration dropped dramatically after the mid-1970s and has since ceased to be a social phenomenon of significance. However, since Malta joined the EU in 2004
       <a href="/wiki/Expatriate" title="Expatriate">
        expatriate
       </a>
       communities emerged in a number of European countries particularly in
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_in_Belgium" title="Maltese in Belgium">
        Belgium
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg">
        Luxembourg
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
        Education
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Education">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Malta" title="Education in Malta">
        Education in Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_schools_in_Malta" title="List of schools in Malta">
        List of schools in Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Uni-20malta.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Uni-20malta.jpg/220px-Uni-20malta.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Uni-20malta.jpg/330px-Uni-20malta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Uni-20malta.jpg/440px-Uni-20malta.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Uni-20malta.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/University_of_Malta" title="University of Malta">
          University of Malta
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bibliothek_in_Malta,_in_Valletta.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3888" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Bibliothek_in_Malta%2C_in_Valletta.JPG/220px-Bibliothek_in_Malta%2C_in_Valletta.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Bibliothek_in_Malta%2C_in_Valletta.JPG/330px-Bibliothek_in_Malta%2C_in_Valletta.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Bibliothek_in_Malta%2C_in_Valletta.JPG/440px-Bibliothek_in_Malta%2C_in_Valletta.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bibliothek_in_Malta,_in_Valletta.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Library in
         <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">
          Valletta
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Primary schooling has been compulsory since 1946; secondary education up to the age of sixteen was made compulsory in 1971. The state and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" title="Roman Catholic Church">
        Church
       </a>
       provide education free of charge, both running a number of schools in Malta and
       <a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">
        Gozo
       </a>
       , including
       <a href="/wiki/De_La_Salle_College_(Malta)" title="De La Salle College (Malta)">
        De La Salle College
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Cospicua" title="Cospicua">
        Cospicua
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/St_Aloysius%27_College_(Malta)" title="St Aloysius' College (Malta)">
        St. Aloysius' College
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Birkirkara" title="Birkirkara">
        Birkirkara
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Paul%27s_Missionary_College" title="St. Paul's Missionary College">
        St. Paul's Missionary College
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Rabat,_Malta" title="Rabat, Malta">
        Rabat, Malta
       </a>
       , St. Joseph's School in
       <a href="/wiki/Blata_l-Bajda" title="Blata l-Bajda">
        Blata l-Bajda
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_schools_in_Malta" title="List of schools in Malta">
        Saint Monica Girls' School
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Mosta" title="Mosta">
        Mosta
       </a>
       . As of 2006
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , state schools are organised into networks known as Colleges and incorporate kindergarten schools, primary and secondary schools. A number of private schools are run in Malta, including
       <a href="/wiki/San_Andrea_School" title="San Andrea School">
        San Andrea School
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/San_Anton_School" title="San Anton School">
        San Anton School
       </a>
       in the valley of L-Imselliet (l/o
       <a href="/wiki/M%C4%A1arr" title="Mġarr">
        Mġarr
       </a>
       ),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Martin%27s_College" title="St. Martin's College">
        St. Martin's College
       </a>
       in Swatar and St. Michael's School in
       <a href="/wiki/San_%C4%A0wann" title="San Ġwann">
        San Ġwann
       </a>
       . St. Catherine's High School, Pembroke offers an International Foundation Course for students wishing to learn English before entering mainstream education. As of 2008
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , there are two international schools, Verdala International School and QSI Malta. The state pays a portion of the teachers' salary in Church schools.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
        <a href="#cite_note-220">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Education in Malta is based on the
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Education in the United Kingdom">
        British model
       </a>
       . Primary school lasts six years. At the age of 11 pupils sit for an examination to enter a secondary school, either a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Church_school" title="Church school">
        church school
       </a>
       (the Common Entrance Examination) or a
       <a href="/wiki/State_school" title="State school">
        state school
       </a>
       . Pupils sit for SEC
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/O-level" title="O-level">
        O-level
       </a>
       examinations at the age of 16, with passes obligatory in certain subjects such as mathematics, English and
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">
        Maltese
       </a>
       . Pupils may opt to continue studying at a
       <a href="/wiki/Sixth_form_college" title="Sixth form college">
        sixth form college
       </a>
       such as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gan_Frangisk_Abela_Junior_College" title="Gan Frangisk Abela Junior College">
        Gan Frangisk Abela Junior College
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/St_Aloysius%27_College_(Malta)" title="St Aloysius' College (Malta)">
        St. Aloysius' College
       </a>
       , Giovanni Curmi Higher Secondary,
       <a href="/wiki/De_La_Salle_College_(Malta)" title="De La Salle College (Malta)">
        De La Salle College
       </a>
       , St Edward's College, or else at another post-secondary institution such as
       <a href="/wiki/MCAST" title="MCAST">
        MCAST
       </a>
       . The sixth form course lasts for two years, at the end of which students sit for the Matriculation examination. Subject to their performance, students may then apply for an undergraduate
       <a href="/wiki/Academic_degree" title="Academic degree">
        degree
       </a>
       or diploma.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Malta" title="University of Malta">
        University of Malta
       </a>
       (U.o.M.) provides Tertiary education at diploma, undergraduate and postgraduate level. The adult
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" title="Literacy rate">
        literacy rate
       </a>
       is 99.5 per cent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
        <a href="#cite_note-221">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Maltese and English are both used to teach pupils at primary and secondary school level, and both languages are also compulsory subjects.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_school_(government_funded)" title="Public school (government funded)">
        Public schools
       </a>
       tend to use both Maltese and English in a balanced manner. Private schools prefer to use English for teaching, as is also the case with most departments of the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Malta" title="University of Malta">
        University of Malta
       </a>
       ; this has a limiting effect on the capacity and development of the Maltese language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LinguisticView_199-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-LinguisticView-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Most university courses are in English.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MED_196-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-MED-196">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template">
        <span style="white-space: nowrap;">
         [
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot" title="Wikipedia:Link rot">
           <span title=" Dead link since September 2015">
            dead link
           </span>
          </a>
         </i>
         ]
        </span>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Of the total number of pupils studying a first foreign language at secondary level, 51 per cent take Italian whilst 38 per cent take French. Other choices include German, Russian, Spanish, Latin, Chinese and Arabic.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LinguisticView_199-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-LinguisticView-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template">
        <span style="white-space: nowrap;">
         [
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot" title="Wikipedia:Link rot">
           <span title=" Dead link since September 2015">
            dead link
           </span>
          </a>
         </i>
         ]
        </span>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
        <a href="#cite_note-222">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta is also a popular destination to study the English language, attracting over 80,000 students in 2012.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
        <a href="#cite_note-223">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">
        Healthcare
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Healthcare">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Malta" title="Healthcare in Malta">
        Healthcare in Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_Valletta_-_Triq_il-Mediterran-Triq_it-Tramuntana_-_Mediterranean_Conference_Centre_01_ies.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="5616" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Malta_-_Valletta_-_Triq_il-Mediterran-Triq_it-Tramuntana_-_Mediterranean_Conference_Centre_01_ies.jpg/220px-Malta_-_Valletta_-_Triq_il-Mediterran-Triq_it-Tramuntana_-_Mediterranean_Conference_Centre_01_ies.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Malta_-_Valletta_-_Triq_il-Mediterran-Triq_it-Tramuntana_-_Mediterranean_Conference_Centre_01_ies.jpg/330px-Malta_-_Valletta_-_Triq_il-Mediterran-Triq_it-Tramuntana_-_Mediterranean_Conference_Centre_01_ies.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Malta_-_Valletta_-_Triq_il-Mediterran-Triq_it-Tramuntana_-_Mediterranean_Conference_Centre_01_ies.jpg/440px-Malta_-_Valletta_-_Triq_il-Mediterran-Triq_it-Tramuntana_-_Mediterranean_Conference_Centre_01_ies.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_Valletta_-_Triq_il-Mediterran-Triq_it-Tramuntana_-_Mediterranean_Conference_Centre_01_ies.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Sacra Infermeria was used as a hospital from the 16th to 20th centuries. It is now the
         <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Conference_Centre" title="Mediterranean Conference Centre">
          Mediterranean Conference Centre
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mater_Dei_01.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2898" data-file-width="4347" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Mater_Dei_01.jpg/220px-Mater_Dei_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Mater_Dei_01.jpg/330px-Mater_Dei_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Mater_Dei_01.jpg/440px-Mater_Dei_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mater_Dei_01.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mater_Dei_Hospital" title="Mater Dei Hospital">
          Mater Dei Hospital
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MMSA_Checking_Blood_Pressure.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/13/MMSA_Checking_Blood_Pressure.JPG/220px-MMSA_Checking_Blood_Pressure.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/13/MMSA_Checking_Blood_Pressure.JPG/330px-MMSA_Checking_Blood_Pressure.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/13/MMSA_Checking_Blood_Pressure.JPG/440px-MMSA_Checking_Blood_Pressure.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MMSA_Checking_Blood_Pressure.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Medical Student taking blood pressure during an event organised by the local medical student association
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Malta has a long history of providing
       <a href="/wiki/Publicly_funded_health_care" title="Publicly funded health care">
        publicly funded health care
       </a>
       . The first hospital recorded in the country was already functioning by 1372.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
        <a href="#cite_note-224">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Today, Malta has both a public healthcare system, known as the government healthcare service, where healthcare is free at the point of delivery, and a
       <a href="/wiki/Private_healthcare" title="Private healthcare">
        private healthcare
       </a>
       system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
        <a href="#cite_note-225">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
        <a href="#cite_note-226">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Malta has a strong general practitioner-delivered primary care base and the public hospitals provide secondary and tertiary care. The Maltese Ministry of Health advises foreign residents to take out private medical insurance.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
        <a href="#cite_note-227">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta also boasts voluntary organisations such as Alpha Medical (Advanced Care), the Emergency Fire &amp; Rescue Unit (E.F.R.U.), St John Ambulance and Red Cross Malta who provide first aid/nursing services during events involving crowds.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Mater_Dei_Hospital" title="Mater Dei Hospital">
        Mater Dei Hospital
       </a>
       , Malta's primary hospital, opened in 2007. It has one of the largest medical buildings in Europe.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Malta" title="University of Malta">
        University of Malta
       </a>
       has a
       <a href="/wiki/Medical_school" title="Medical school">
        medical school
       </a>
       and a Faculty of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Health_Sciences" title="Health Sciences">
        Health Sciences
       </a>
       , the latter offering diploma, degree (BSc) and postgraduate degree courses in a number of health care disciplines.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Medical_Association_of_Malta" title="Medical Association of Malta">
        Medical Association of Malta
       </a>
       represents practitioners of the medical profession. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Malta_Medical_Students%27_Association" title="Malta Medical Students' Association">
        Malta Medical Students' Association
       </a>
       (MMSA) is a separate body representing Maltese medical students, and is a member of
       <a href="/wiki/European_Medical_Students%27_Association" title="European Medical Students' Association">
        EMSA
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/International_Federation_of_Medical_Students%27_Associations" title="International Federation of Medical Students' Associations">
        IFMSA
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Malta_Institute_for_Medical_Education" title="Malta Institute for Medical Education">
        MIME
       </a>
       , the Maltese Institute for Medical Education, is an institute set up recently to provide CME to physicians in Malta as well as medical students. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foundation_Program" title="Foundation Program">
        Foundation Program
       </a>
       followed in the UK has been introduced in Malta to stem the 'brain drain' of newly graduated physicians to the British Isles. The
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Malta_Association_of_Dental_Students&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Malta Association of Dental Students (page does not exist)">
        Malta Association of Dental Students
       </a>
       (MADS) is a student association set up to promote the rights of Dental Surgery Students studying within the faculty of Dental Surgery of the University of Malta. It is affiliated with
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=IADS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="IADS (page does not exist)">
        IADS
       </a>
       , the International Association of Dental Students.
      </p>
      <p>
       See also
       <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Malta" title="Health in Malta">
        Health in Malta
       </a>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Culture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Malta" title="Culture of Malta">
        Culture of Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The culture of Malta reflects the various cultures from the Phoenicians to the British, that have come into contact with the Maltese Islands throughout the centuries, including neighbouring Mediterranean cultures, and the cultures of the nations that ruled Malta for long periods of time prior to its
       <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(Malta)" title="Independence Day (Malta)">
        independence
       </a>
       in 1964.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Music">
        Music
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Music">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Malta" title="Music of Malta">
        Music of Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Manoel_theatre_(12851453033).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="347" data-file-width="649" height="118" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Manoel_theatre_%2812851453033%29.jpg/220px-Manoel_theatre_%2812851453033%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Manoel_theatre_%2812851453033%29.jpg/330px-Manoel_theatre_%2812851453033%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Manoel_theatre_%2812851453033%29.jpg/440px-Manoel_theatre_%2812851453033%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Manoel_theatre_(12851453033).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Manoel_Theatre" title="Manoel Theatre">
          Manoel Theatre
         </a>
         , Europe's third-oldest working theatre. Now Malta's National Theatre and home to the
         <a href="/wiki/Malta_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="Malta Philharmonic Orchestra">
          Malta Philharmonic Orchestra
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       While Maltese music today is largely Western, traditional Maltese music includes what is known as
       <a href="/wiki/G%C4%A7ana_(folk_music)" title="Għana (folk music)">
        għana
       </a>
       . This consists of background
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_guitar" title="Folk guitar">
        folk guitar
       </a>
       music, while a few people, generally men, take it in turns to argue a point in a sing-song voice. The aim of the lyrics, which are improvised, is to create a friendly yet challenging atmosphere, and it takes a number of years of practice to be able to combine the required artistic qualities with the ability to
       <a href="/wiki/Debate" title="Debate">
        debate
       </a>
       effectively.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">
        Literature
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Literature">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_literature" title="Maltese literature">
        Maltese literature
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Documented Maltese literature is over 200 years old. However, a recently unearthed love ballad testifies to literary activity in the local tongue from the Medieval period. Malta followed a Romantic literary tradition, culminating in the works of
       <a href="/wiki/Dun_Karm_Psaila" title="Dun Karm Psaila">
        Dun Karm Psaila
       </a>
       , Malta's National Poet. Subsequent writers like
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ruzar_Briffa" title="Ruzar Briffa">
        Ruzar Briffa
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Karmenu_Vassallo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Karmenu Vassallo (page does not exist)">
        Karmenu Vassallo
       </a>
       tried to estrange themselves from the rigidity of formal themes and versification.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The next generation of writers, including
       <a href="/wiki/Karl_Schembri" title="Karl Schembri">
        Karl Schembri
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Immanuel_Mifsud" title="Immanuel Mifsud">
        Immanuel Mifsud
       </a>
       , widened the tracks further, especially in prose and poetry,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
        <a href="#cite_note-228">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:San_Giulian,_Marina.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="960" data-file-width="1280" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/San_Giulian%2C_Marina.jpg/220px-San_Giulian%2C_Marina.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/San_Giulian%2C_Marina.jpg/330px-San_Giulian%2C_Marina.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/San_Giulian%2C_Marina.jpg/440px-San_Giulian%2C_Marina.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:San_Giulian,_Marina.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Typical architecture built in recent years in Malta
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Art_and_architecture">
        Art and architecture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Art and architecture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vallettaupperbarraccagardens.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Vallettaupperbarraccagardens.JPG/220px-Vallettaupperbarraccagardens.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Vallettaupperbarraccagardens.JPG/330px-Vallettaupperbarraccagardens.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Vallettaupperbarraccagardens.JPG/440px-Vallettaupperbarraccagardens.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vallettaupperbarraccagardens.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Lower Barrakka Gardens
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Maltese architecture has been influenced by many different Mediterranean cultures and British architecture over its history. The first settlers on the island constructed
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%A0gantija" title="Ġgantija">
        Ġgantija
       </a>
       , one of the oldest manmade freestanding structures in the world. The Neolithic temple builders 3800–2500 BC endowed the numerous temples of Malta and Gozo with intricate bas relief designs, including spirals evocative of the tree of life and animal portraits, designs painted in red ochre, ceramics and a vast collection of human form sculptures, particularly the Venus of Malta. These can be viewed at the temples themselves (most notably, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hypogeum_of_%C4%A6al-Saflieni" title="Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni">
        Hypogeum
       </a>
       and Tarxien Temples), and at the National Museum of Archaeology in
       <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">
        Valletta
       </a>
       . Malta's temples such as Imnajdra are full of history and have a story behind them. Malta is currently undergoing several large-scale building projects, including the construction of
       <a href="/wiki/SmartCity_Malta" title="SmartCity Malta">
        SmartCity Malta
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/M-Towers" title="M-Towers">
        M-Towers
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Pendergardens" title="Pendergardens">
        Pendergardens
       </a>
       , while areas such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Valletta_Waterfront" title="Valletta Waterfront">
        Valletta Waterfront
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Tign%C3%A9_Point" title="Tigné Point">
        Tigné Point
       </a>
       have been or are being renovated.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Roman period introduced highly decorative mosaic floors, marble colonnades and classical statuary, remnants of which are beautifully preserved and presented in the Roman Domus, a country villa just outside the walls of
       <a href="/wiki/Mdina" title="Mdina">
        Mdina
       </a>
       . The early Christian frescoes that decorate the
       <a href="/wiki/Catacombs" title="Catacombs">
        catacombs
       </a>
       beneath Malta reveal a propensity for eastern,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine" title="Byzantine">
        Byzantine
       </a>
       tastes. These tastes continued to inform the endeavours of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Medieval" title="Medieval">
        medieval
       </a>
       Maltese artists, but they were increasingly influenced by the
       <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_art" title="Romanesque art">
        Romanesque
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Southern_Gothic" title="Southern Gothic">
        Southern Gothic
       </a>
       movements. Towards the end of the 15th century, Maltese artists, like their counterparts in neighbouring Sicily, came under the influence of the School of
       <a href="/wiki/Antonello_da_Messina" title="Antonello da Messina">
        Antonello da Messina
       </a>
       , which introduced
       <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">
        Renaissance
       </a>
       ideals and concepts to the decorative arts in Malta.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hopeandoptimism1_229-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-hopeandoptimism1-229">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CaravaggioJeromeValletta.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="716" data-file-width="1037" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/CaravaggioJeromeValletta.jpg/220px-CaravaggioJeromeValletta.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/CaravaggioJeromeValletta.jpg/330px-CaravaggioJeromeValletta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/CaravaggioJeromeValletta.jpg/440px-CaravaggioJeromeValletta.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CaravaggioJeromeValletta.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Saint Jerome Writing, by Caravaggio. Held in St John's Co-Cathedral, Valletta.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The artistic heritage of Malta blossomed under the
       <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">
        Knights of St. John
       </a>
       , who brought Italian and Flemish
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mannerist" title="Mannerist">
        Mannerist
       </a>
       painters to decorate their palaces and the churches of these islands, most notably,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Matteo_Perez_d%27Aleccio" title="Matteo Perez d'Aleccio">
        Matteo Perez d'Aleccio
       </a>
       , whose works appear in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grandmaster%27s_Palace_in_Valletta" title="Grandmaster's Palace in Valletta">
        Magisterial Palace
       </a>
       and in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._John%27s_Co-Cathedral" title="St. John's Co-Cathedral">
        Conventual Church of St. John
       </a>
       in Valletta, and Filippo Paladini, who was active in Malta from 1590 to 1595. For many years, Mannerism continued to inform the tastes and ideals of local Maltese artists.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hopeandoptimism1_229-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-hopeandoptimism1-229">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The arrival in Malta of
       <a href="/wiki/Caravaggio" title="Caravaggio">
        Caravaggio
       </a>
       , who painted at least seven works during his 15-month stay on these islands, further revolutionised local art. Two of Caravaggio's most notable works,
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Beheading_of_Saint_John_the_Baptist_(Caravaggio)" title="The Beheading of Saint John the Baptist (Caravaggio)">
         The Beheading of Saint John the Baptist
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Jerome_Writing_(Valletta)" title="Saint Jerome Writing (Valletta)">
         Saint Jerome Writing
        </a>
       </i>
       , are on display in the
       <a href="/wiki/Oratory_(worship)" title="Oratory (worship)">
        Oratory
       </a>
       of the Conventual Church of St. John. His legacy is evident in the works of local artists Giulio Cassarino (1582–1637) and Stefano Erardi (1630–1716). However, the
       <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">
        Baroque
       </a>
       movement that followed was destined to have the most enduring impact on Maltese art and architecture. The glorious vault paintings of the celebrated Calabrese artist,
       <a href="/wiki/Mattia_Preti" title="Mattia Preti">
        Mattia Preti
       </a>
       transformed the severe, Mannerist interior of the Conventual Church St. John into a Baroque masterpiece. Preti spent the last 40 years of his life in Malta, where he created many of his finest works, now on display in the Museum of Fine Arts in
       <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">
        Valletta
       </a>
       . During this period, local sculptor
       <a href="/wiki/Melchiorre_Caf%C3%A0" title="Melchiorre Cafà">
        Melchior Gafà
       </a>
       (1639–1667) emerged as one of the top Baroque sculptors of the Roman School.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Siege_of_malta_3.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="459" data-file-width="700" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Siege_of_malta_3.jpg/220px-Siege_of_malta_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Siege_of_malta_3.jpg/330px-Siege_of_malta_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Siege_of_malta_3.jpg/440px-Siege_of_malta_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Siege_of_malta_3.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          The Siege of Malta – Flight of the Turks
         </i>
         , by Matteo Perez d'Aleccio
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       During the 17th and 18th century,
       <a href="/wiki/Naples" title="Naples">
        Neapolitan
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">
        Rococo
       </a>
       influences emerged in the works of the Italian painters
       <a href="/wiki/Luca_Giordano" title="Luca Giordano">
        Luca Giordano
       </a>
       (1632–1705) and
       <a href="/wiki/Francesco_Solimena" title="Francesco Solimena">
        Francesco Solimena
       </a>
       (1657–1747), and these developments can be seen in the work of their Maltese contemporaries such as Giovanni Nicola Buhagiar (1698–1752) and Francesco Zahra (1710–1773). The Rococo movement was greatly enhanced by the relocation to Malta of Antoine de Favray (1706–1798), who assumed the position of court painter to Grand Master Pinto in 1744.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neo-classicism" title="Neo-classicism">
        Neo-classicism
       </a>
       made some inroads among local Maltese artists in the late-18th century, but this trend was reversed in the early 19th century, as the local Church authorities – perhaps in an effort to strengthen Catholic resolve against the perceived threat of Protestantism during the early days of British rule in Malta – favoured and avidly promoted the religious themes embraced by the
       <a href="/wiki/Nazarene_movement" title="Nazarene movement">
        Nazarene movement
       </a>
       of artists.
       <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">
        Romanticism
       </a>
       , tempered by the naturalism introduced to Malta by
       <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Cal%C3%AC" title="Giuseppe Calì">
        Giuseppe Calì
       </a>
       , informed the "salon" artists of the early 20th century, including Edward and Robert Caruana Dingli.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
        <a href="#cite_note-230">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Parliament established the National School of Art in the 1920s. During the reconstruction period that followed the Second World War, the emergence of the "Modern Art Group", whose members included Josef Kalleya (1898–1998), George Preca (1909–1984), Anton Inglott (1915–1945), Emvin Cremona (1919–1986), Frank Portelli (b. 1922), Antoine Camilleri (b. 1922) and Esprit Barthet (b. 1919) greatly enhanced the local art scene. In Valletta, the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Fine_Arts,_Malta" title="National Museum of Fine Arts, Malta">
        National Museum of Fine Arts
       </a>
       features work from artists such as
       <a href="/wiki/H._Craig_Hanna" title="H. Craig Hanna">
        H. Craig Hanna
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MaltaInd_231-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MaltaInd-231">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
        Cuisine
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Cuisine">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_cuisine" title="Maltese cuisine">
        Maltese cuisine
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Maltese_dishes" title="List of Maltese dishes">
        List of Maltese dishes
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_Pastizzi.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="230" data-file-width="230" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Malta_Pastizzi.JPG/170px-Malta_Pastizzi.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fc/Malta_Pastizzi.JPG 1.5x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_Pastizzi.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pastizzi" title="Pastizzi">
           Pastizzi
          </a>
         </i>
         , a typical Maltese snack
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_ftira.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="283" data-file-width="361" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Malta_ftira.JPG/170px-Malta_ftira.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Malta_ftira.JPG/255px-Malta_ftira.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Malta_ftira.JPG/340px-Malta_ftira.JPG 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_ftira.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ftira" title="Ftira">
           Ftira
          </a>
         </i>
         , a type of Maltese bread
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Maltese cuisine shows strong Sicilian and English influences as well as influences of
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_cuisine" title="Spanish cuisine">
        Spanish
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Maghreb_cuisine" title="Maghreb cuisine">
        Maghrebin
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proven%C3%A7al_cuisine" title="Provençal cuisine">
        Provençal
       </a>
       cuisines. A number of regional variations, particularly with regards to Gozo, can be noted as well as seasonal variations associated with the seasonal availability of produce and Christian feasts (such as
       <a href="/wiki/Lent" title="Lent">
        Lent
       </a>
       , Easter and Christmas). Food has been important historically in the development of a national identity in particular the traditional
       <i>
        fenkata
       </i>
       (i.e., the eating of stewed or fried rabbit).
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Customs">
        Customs
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Customs">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_folklore" title="Maltese folklore">
        Maltese folklore
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       A 2010
       <a href="/wiki/Charities_Aid_Foundation" title="Charities Aid Foundation">
        Charities Aid Foundation
       </a>
       study found that the Maltese were the most generous people in the world, with 83% contributing to charity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
        <a href="#cite_note-232">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Maltese folktales include various stories about mysterious creatures and supernatural events. These were most comprehensively compiled by the scholar (and pioneer in Maltese
       <a href="/wiki/Archaeology" title="Archaeology">
        archaeology
       </a>
       )
       <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Magri" title="Manuel Magri">
        Manwel Magri
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
        <a href="#cite_note-233">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in his core criticism "
       <i>
        Ħrejjef Missirijietna
       </i>
       " ("Fables from our Forefathers"). This collection of material inspired subsequent researchers and academics to gather traditional
       <a href="/wiki/Folklore" title="Folklore">
        tales
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fable" title="Fable">
