        fables
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Legend" title="Legend">
        legends
       </a>
       from all over the Archipelago.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Magri's work also inspired a series of comic books (released by Klabb Kotba Maltin in 1984): the titles included
       <i>
        Bin is-Sultan Jiźźewweġ x-Xebba tat-Tronġiet Mewwija
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Ir-Rjieħ
       </i>
       . Many of these stories have been popularly re-written as Children's literature by authors writing in
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">
        Maltese
       </a>
       , such as
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Trevor_%C5%BBahra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Trevor Żahra (page does not exist)">
        Trevor Żahra
       </a>
       . While giants, witches and dragons feature in many of the stories, some contain entirely Maltese creatures like the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kaw_kaw" title="Kaw kaw">
        Kaw kaw
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Il-Bellieg%C4%A7a" title="Il-Belliegħa">
        Il-Belliegħa
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L-Im%C4%A7alla" title="L-Imħalla">
        L-Imħalla
       </a>
       among others. The traditional Maltese obsession with maintaining spiritual (or ritual) purity
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
        <a href="#cite_note-234">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
       means that many of these creatures have the role of guarding forbidden or restricted areas and attacking individuals who broke the strict codes of conduct that characterised the island's pre-industrial society.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Traditions">
        Traditions
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Traditions">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Traditional Maltese proverbs reveal a cultural importance of childbearing and fertility: "
       <i>
        iż-żwieġ mingħajr tarbija ma fihx tgawdija
       </i>
       " (a childless marriage cannot be a happy one). This is a belief that Malta shares with many other Mediterranean cultures. In Maltese folktales the local variant of the classic closing formula, "and they all lived happily ever after" is "
       <i>
        u għammru u tgħammru, u spiċċat
       </i>
       " (and they lived together, and they had children together, and the tale is finished).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
        <a href="#cite_note-235">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Rural Malta shares in common with Mediterranean society a number of superstitions regarding fertility, menstruation and pregnancy, including the avoidance of cemeteries during the months leading up to childbirth, and avoiding the preparation of certain foods during menses. Pregnant women are encouraged to satisfy their
       <a href="/wiki/Food_craving" title="Food craving">
        cravings
       </a>
       for specific foods, out of fear that their unborn child will bear a representational birth mark (Maltese:
       <i>
        xewqa
       </i>
       , literally "desire" or "craving"). Maltese and Sicilian women also share certain traditions that are believed to predict the sex of an unborn child, such as the cycle of the moon on the anticipated date of birth, whether the baby is carried "high" or "low" during pregnancy, and the movement of a wedding ring, dangled on a string above the abdomen (sideways denoting a girl, back and forth denoting a boy).
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Traditionally, Maltese newborns were baptised as promptly as possible, should the child die in infancy without receiving this vital Sacrament; and partly because according to Maltese (and Sicilian) folklore an unbaptised child is not yet a Christian, but "still a Turk". Traditional Maltese delicacies served at a baptismal feast include
       <i>
        biskuttini tal-magħmudija
       </i>
       (almond macaroons covered in white or pink icing),
       <i>
        it-torta tal-marmorata
       </i>
       (a spicy, heart-shaped tart of chocolate-flavoured almond paste), and a liqueur known as
       <i>
        rożolin
       </i>
       , made with rose petals, violets and almonds.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On a child's first birthday, in a tradition that still survives today, Maltese parents would organise a game known as
       <i>
        il-quċċija
       </i>
       , where a variety of symbolic objects would be randomly placed around the seated child. These may include a hard-boiled egg, a Bible,
       <a href="/wiki/Crucifix" title="Crucifix">
        crucifix
       </a>
       or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rosary_beads" title="Rosary beads">
        rosary beads
       </a>
       , a book, and so on. Whichever object the child shows most interest in is said to reveal the child's path and fortunes in adulthood.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Money refers to a rich future while a book expresses intelligence and a possible career as a teacher. Infants who select a pencil or pen will be writers. Choosing Bibles or rosary beads refers to a clerical or monastic life. If the child chooses a hard-boiled egg, it will have a long life and many children. More recent additions include calculators (refers to accounting), thread (fashion) and wooden spoons (cooking and a great appetite).
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Maltesewedding.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="317" data-file-width="540" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4e/Maltesewedding.jpg/220px-Maltesewedding.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4e/Maltesewedding.jpg/330px-Maltesewedding.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4e/Maltesewedding.jpg/440px-Maltesewedding.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Maltesewedding.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Re-enactment of a traditional Maltese 18th century wedding
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Traditional Maltese weddings featured the bridal party walking in procession beneath an ornate canopy, from the home of the bride's family to the parish church, with singers trailing behind serenading the bride and groom. The Maltese word for this custom is
       <i>
        il-ġilwa
       </i>
       . This custom along with many others has long since disappeared from the islands, in the face of modern practices.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       New wives would wear the
       <a href="/wiki/G%C4%A7onnella" title="Għonnella">
        għonnella
       </a>
       , a traditional item of Maltese clothing. However, it is no longer worn in modern Malta. Today's couples are married in churches or chapels in the village or town of their choice. The nuptials are usually followed by a lavish and joyous wedding reception, often including several hundred guests. Occasionally, couples will try to incorporate elements of the traditional Maltese wedding in their celebration. A resurgent interest in the traditional wedding was evident in May 2007, when thousands of Maltese and tourists attended a traditional Maltese wedding in the style of the 16th century, in the village of
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%BBurrieq" title="Żurrieq">
        Żurrieq
       </a>
       . This included
       <i>
        il-ġilwa
       </i>
       , which led the bride and groom to a wedding ceremony that took place on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parvis" title="Parvis">
        parvis
       </a>
       of St. Andrew's Chapel. The reception that followed featured folklore music (
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G%C4%A7ana" title="Għana">
         għana
        </a>
       </i>
       ) and dancing.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Festivals">
        Festivals
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Festivals">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_statue_of_St._George_issuing_from_the_Basilica_on_the_third_Sunday_of_July.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2288" data-file-width="1712" height="294" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/The_statue_of_St._George_issuing_from_the_Basilica_on_the_third_Sunday_of_July.jpg/220px-The_statue_of_St._George_issuing_from_the_Basilica_on_the_third_Sunday_of_July.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/The_statue_of_St._George_issuing_from_the_Basilica_on_the_third_Sunday_of_July.jpg/330px-The_statue_of_St._George_issuing_from_the_Basilica_on_the_third_Sunday_of_July.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/The_statue_of_St._George_issuing_from_the_Basilica_on_the_third_Sunday_of_July.jpg/440px-The_statue_of_St._George_issuing_from_the_Basilica_on_the_third_Sunday_of_July.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_statue_of_St._George_issuing_from_the_Basilica_on_the_third_Sunday_of_July.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The statue of St. George at the
         <i>
          festa
         </i>
         of
         <a href="/wiki/Victoria,_Gozo" title="Victoria, Gozo">
          Victoria, Gozo
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Local festivals, similar to those in Southern Italy, are commonplace in Malta and Gozo, celebrating weddings,
       <a href="/wiki/Baptism" title="Baptism">
        christenings
       </a>
       and, most prominently,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saints" title="Saints">
        saints
       </a>
       ' days, honouring the patron saint of the local parish. On saints' days, the
       <i>
        festa
       </i>
       reaches its apex with a
       <a href="/wiki/Mass_(liturgy)" title="Mass (liturgy)">
        High Mass
       </a>
       featuring a sermon on the life and achievements of the patron saint, after which a
       <a href="/wiki/Statue" title="Statue">
        statue
       </a>
       of the religious patron is taken around the local streets in solemn procession, with the faithful following in respectful prayer. The atmosphere of religious devotion quickly gives way to several days of celebration and revelry: band processions,
       <a href="/wiki/Fireworks" title="Fireworks">
        fireworks
       </a>
       , and late-night parties.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_Carnival" title="Maltese Carnival">
        Carnival
       </a>
       (Maltese:
       <i>
        il-karnival ta' Malta
       </i>
       ) has had an important place on the cultural calendar after
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Master_(order)" title="Grand Master (order)">
        Grand Master
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Piero_de_Ponte" title="Piero de Ponte">
        Piero de Ponte
       </a>
       introduced it to the islands in 1535. It is held during the week leading up to
       <a href="/wiki/Ash_Wednesday" title="Ash Wednesday">
        Ash Wednesday
       </a>
       , and typically includes masked balls, fancy dress and grotesque mask competitions, lavish late-night parties, a colourful, ticker-tape parade of allegorical
       <a href="/wiki/Float_(parade)" title="Float (parade)">
        floats
       </a>
       presided over by King Carnival (Maltese:
       <i>
        ir-Re tal-Karnival
       </i>
       ), marching bands and costumed revellers.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holy_Week_in_Malta" title="Holy Week in Malta">
        Holy Week
       </a>
       (Maltese:
       <i>
        il-Ġimgħa Mqaddsa
       </i>
       ) starts on
       <a href="/wiki/Palm_Sunday" title="Palm Sunday">
        Palm Sunday
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Ħadd il-Palm
       </i>
       ) and ends on
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Easter_Sunday" title="Easter Sunday">
        Easter Sunday
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Ħadd il-Għid
       </i>
       ). Numerous religious traditions, most of them inherited from one generation to the next, are part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Easter" title="Easter">
        paschal
       </a>
       celebrations in the Maltese Islands, honouring the death and resurrection of Jesus.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Mnarja, or l-Imnarja (pronounced
       <i>
        lim-nar-ya
       </i>
       ) is one of the most important dates on the Maltese cultural calendar. Officially, it is a national festival dedicated to the feast of
       <a href="/wiki/Saint" title="Saint">
        Saints
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Peter" title="St. Peter">
        Peter
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saul_of_Tarsus" title="Saul of Tarsus">
        St. Paul
       </a>
       . Its roots can be traced back to the pagan
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">
        Roman
       </a>
       feast of
       <i>
        Luminaria
       </i>
       (literally, "the illumination"), when torches and bonfires lit up the early summer night of 29 June.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A national feast since the rule of the
       <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">
        Knights
       </a>
       , Mnarja is a traditional Maltese festival of food, religion and music. The festivities still commence today with the reading of the
       <i>
        "bandu"
       </i>
       , an official governmental announcement, which has been read on this day in Malta since the 16th century. Originally, Mnarja was celebrated outside St. Paul's Grotto, in the north of Malta. However, by 1613 the focus of the festivities had shifted to the Cathedral of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paul_of_Tarsus" title="Paul of Tarsus">
        St. Paul
       </a>
       , in
       <a href="/wiki/Mdina" title="Mdina">
        Mdina
       </a>
       , and featured torchlight processions, the firing of 100 petards, horseraces, and races for men, boys and slaves. Modern Mnarja festivals take place in and around the woodlands of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buskett" title="Buskett">
        Buskett
       </a>
       , just outside the town of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rabat_Malta" title="Rabat Malta">
        Rabat
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       It is said that under the Knights, this was the one day in the year when the Maltese were allowed to hunt and eat
       <a href="/wiki/Hare" title="Hare">
        wild rabbit
       </a>
       , which was otherwise reserved for the hunting pleasures of the Knights. The close connection between Mnarja and
       <a href="/wiki/Rabbit_stew" title="Rabbit stew">
        rabbit stew
       </a>
       (Maltese:
       <i>
        "fenkata"
       </i>
       ) remains strong today.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1854 British governor
       <a href="/wiki/William_Reid_(British_Army_officer)" title="William Reid (British Army officer)">
        William Reid
       </a>
       launched an agricultural show at Buskett which is still being held today. The farmers' exhibition is still a seminal part of the Mnarja festivities today.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Mnarja today is one of the few occasions when participants may hear traditional Maltese "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G%C4%A7ana" title="Għana">
        għana
       </a>
       ". Traditionally, grooms would promise to take their brides to Mnarja during the first year of marriage. For luck, many of the brides would attend in their wedding gown and veil, although this custom has long since disappeared from the islands.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Isle of MTV is a one-day music festival produced and broadcast on an annual basis by MTV. The festival has been arranged annually in Malta since 2007, with major pop artists performing each year. 2012 saw the performances of worldwide acclaimed artists Flo Rida, Nelly Furtado and Will.I.Am at Fosos Square in Floriana. Over 50,000 people attended, which marked the biggest attendance so far.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
        <a href="#cite_note-236">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2009 the first New Year's Eve street party was organised in Malta, parallel to what major countries in the world organise. Although the event was not highly advertised, and was controversial due to the closing of an arterial street on the day, it is deemed to have been successful and will most likely be organised every year.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Malta International Fireworks Festival is an annual festival that has been arranged in the Grand Harbour of Valletta since 2003. The festival offers fireworks displays of a number of Maltese as well as foreign fireworks factories. The festival is usually held in the last week of April every year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
        <a href="#cite_note-237">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
        Media
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Media">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Malta" title="List of newspapers in Malta">
        List of newspapers in Malta
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_radio_stations_in_Malta" title="List of radio stations in Malta">
        List of radio stations in Malta
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Malta" title="Television in Malta">
        Television in Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The most widely read and financially the strongest newspapers are published by Allied Newspapers Ltd., mainly
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Times_of_Malta" title="The Times of Malta">
         The Times of Malta
        </a>
       </i>
       (27 per cent) and its Sunday edition
       <i>
        The Sunday Times of Malta
       </i>
       (51.6 per cent).
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       Due to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bilingualism" title="Bilingualism">
        bilingualism
       </a>
       half of the newspapers are published in English and the other half in
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">
        Maltese
       </a>
       . The Sunday newspaper
       <i>
        It-Torċa
       </i>
       ("The Torch") published by the Union Press, a subsidiary of the
       <a href="/wiki/General_Workers%27_Union_(Malta)" title="General Workers' Union (Malta)">
        General Workers' Union
       </a>
       , is the widest Maltese language paper. Its sister paper,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/L-Orizzont" title="L-Orizzont">
         L-Orizzont
        </a>
       </i>
       ("The Horizon"), is the Maltese daily with biggest circulation. There is a high number of daily or weekly newspapers; there is one paper for every 28,000 people. Advertising, sales and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subsidies" title="Subsidies">
        subsidies
       </a>
       are the three main methods of financing newspapers and magazines. However, most of the papers and magazines tied to institutions are subsidised by the same institutions, they depend on advertising or subsidies from their owners.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-a1_238-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-a1-238">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are eight terrestrial television channels in Malta:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TVM_(Malta)" title="TVM (Malta)">
        TVM
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/TVM2" title="TVM2">
        TVM2
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Parliament_TV_(Malta)" title="Parliament TV (Malta)">
        Parliament TV
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/One_(Maltese_TV_channel)" title="One (Maltese TV channel)">
        One
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/NET_Television_(Malta)" title="NET Television (Malta)">
        NET Television
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Smash_Television" title="Smash Television">
        Smash Television
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=F_Living&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="F Living (page does not exist)">
        F Living
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Xejk" title="Xejk">
        Xejk
       </a>
       . These channels are transmitted by digital terrestrial, free-to-air signals on
       <a href="/wiki/Ultra_high_frequency" title="Ultra high frequency">
        UHF
       </a>
       channel 66.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
        <a href="#cite_note-239">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The state and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Malta" title="List of political parties in Malta">
        political parties
       </a>
       subsidise most of the funding of these television stations. TVM, TVM2 and Parliament TV are operated by
       <a href="/wiki/Public_Broadcasting_Services" title="Public Broadcasting Services">
        Public Broadcasting Services
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Public_broadcasting" title="Public broadcasting">
        national broadcaster
       </a>
       and member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Broadcasting_Union" title="European Broadcasting Union">
        EBU
       </a>
       . Media.link Communications Ltd., the owner of NET Television, and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/One_Productions_Ltd" title="One Productions Ltd">
        One Productions Ltd
       </a>
       ., the owner of One, are affiliated with the
       <a href="/wiki/Nationalist_Party_(Malta)" title="Nationalist Party (Malta)">
        Nationalist
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(Malta)" title="Labour Party (Malta)">
        Labour
       </a>
       parties, respectively. The rest are privately owned. The Malta Broadcasting Authority supervises all local broadcasting stations and ensures their compliance with legal and licence obligations as well as the preservation of due impartiality; in respect of matters of political or industrial controversy or relating to current public policy; while fairly apportioning broadcasting facilities and time between persons belong to different political parties. The Broadcasting Authority ensures that local broadcasting services consist of public, private and community broadcasts that offer varied and comprehensive programming to cater for all interests and tastes.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Malta Communications Authority reported that there were 147,896 pay TV subscriptions active at the end of 2012, which includes analogue and digital cable, pay digital terrestrial TV and IPTV.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
        <a href="#cite_note-240">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       For reference the latest census counts 139,583 households in Malta.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
        <a href="#cite_note-241">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Satellite reception is available to receive other European television networks such as the
       <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">
        BBC
       </a>
       from Great Britain and
       <a href="/wiki/RAI" title="RAI">
        RAI
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Mediaset" title="Mediaset">
        Mediaset
       </a>
       from Italy.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays">
        Holidays
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Holidays">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Malta" title="Public holidays in Malta">
        Public holidays in Malta
       </a>
      </div>
      <center>
       <table class="wikitable">
        <caption>
         Maltese public holidays
        </caption>
        <tr>
         <th>
          Day
         </th>
         <th>
          Holiday
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          1 January
         </td>
         <td>
          New Year's Day
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          10 February
         </td>
         <td>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Shipwreck" title="St Paul's Shipwreck">
           St. Paul's Shipwreck
          </a>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          19 March
         </td>
         <td>
          <a href="/wiki/Saint_Joseph%27s_Day" title="Saint Joseph's Day">
           St. Joseph
          </a>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          31 March
         </td>
         <td>
          <a href="/wiki/Freedom_Day_(Malta)" title="Freedom Day (Malta)">

          </a>
         </td>
        </tr>

         <td>
          March/April (date changes)
         </td>

        </tr>
        <tr>

          <a href="/wiki/International_Workers%27_Day" title="International Workers' Day">

          </a>

        </tr>

         <td>
          7 June
         </td>
         <td>
          <a href="/wiki/Sette_Giugno" title="Sette Giugno">
           Sette Giugno
          </a>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          29 June
         </td>
         <td>
          <a href="/wiki/Feast_of_Saints_Peter_and_Paul" title="Feast of Saints Peter and Paul">
           St. Peter and St. Paul (L-Imnarja)
          </a>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          15 August
         </td>
         <td>
          <a href="/wiki/Assumption_of_Mary" title="Assumption of Mary">
           The Assumption (Santa Marija)
          </a>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          8 September
         </td>
         <td>
          <a href="/wiki/Victory_Day_(Malta)" title="Victory Day (Malta)">
           Our Lady of Victories
          </a>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          21 September
         </td>
         <td>
          <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(Malta)" title="Independence Day (Malta)">

          </a>
         </td>

         <td>

         </td>
         <td>
          <a href="/wiki/Immaculate_Conception" title="Immaculate Conception">

         </td>

        <tr>
         <td>
          25 December
         </td>
         <td>
          Christmas Day
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </center>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">
        Sport
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Sport">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malta_TaQali.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Malta_TaQali.JPG/220px-Malta_TaQali.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Malta_TaQali.JPG/330px-Malta_TaQali.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Malta_TaQali.JPG/440px-Malta_TaQali.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malta_TaQali.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ta%27_Qali_National_Stadium" title="Ta' Qali National Stadium">
          Ta' Qali National Stadium
         </a>
         is the home ground of the
         <a href="/wiki/Malta_national_football_team" title="Malta national football team">
          Malta national football team
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Association football (soccer) is the most popular sport in Malta. The national stadium is called
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ta%27_Qali_Stadium" title="Ta' Qali Stadium">
        Ta' Qali Stadium
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Malta_national_football_team" title="Malta national football team">
        national football team
       </a>
       has won several matches over big opponents that reached the final phases in
       <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">
        World Cups
       </a>
       , such as
       <a href="/wiki/Belgium_national_football_team" title="Belgium national football team">
        Belgium
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungary_National_football_team" title="Hungary National football team">
        Hungary
       </a>
       . Recently a large number of football grounds have been built throughout the island. The top football league in Malta is called the
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_Premier_League" title="Maltese Premier League">
        Maltese Premier League
       </a>
       , and consists of 12 teams.
       <a href="/wiki/Futsal" title="Futsal">
        Futsal
       </a>
       is also very popular.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Water_polo" title="Water polo">
        Water polo
       </a>
       is also very popular in Malta. The
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Malta_national_water_polo_team&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Malta national water polo team (page does not exist)">
        Malta national water polo team
       </a>
       has achieved some great results against strong teams, and has competed in the Olympics twice. Maltese clubs participate in the European Club competitions organised by LEN, are seen as being in the top 10 water polo leagues in Europe.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">
        Rugby league
       </a>
       is played in Malta. In September 2015 the
       <a href="/wiki/Malta_national_rugby_league_team" title="Malta national rugby league team">
        national men's team
       </a>
       was ranked 23rd in the world. The national team are known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Malta_national_rugby_league_team" title="Malta national rugby league team">
        Malta Knights
       </a>
       , and boast players currently playing in the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Superleague" title="European Superleague">
        European Superleague
       </a>
       such as
       <a href="/wiki/Jarrod_Sammut" title="Jarrod Sammut">
        Jarrod Sammut
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jake_Mamo" title="Jake Mamo">
        Jake Mamo
       </a>
       , the most famous player to come from Malta would be former
       <a href="/wiki/South_Sydney_Rabbitohs" title="South Sydney Rabbitohs">
        South Sydney Rabbitohs
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mario_Fenech" title="Mario Fenech">
        Mario Fenech
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">
        Rugby union
       </a>
       is popular in Malta. In March 2014 the
       <a href="/wiki/Malta_national_rugby_union_team" title="Malta national rugby union team">
        national men's team
       </a>
       was ranked 43rd in the world. They have recently been achieving great success, defeating teams including
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden_national_rugby_union_team" title="Sweden national rugby union team">
        Sweden
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Croatia_national_rugby_union_team" title="Croatia national rugby union team">
        Croatia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Latvia_national_rugby_union_team" title="Latvia national rugby union team">
        Latvia
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Motorsport" title="Motorsport">
        Motorsport
       </a>
       includes drag racing represented by the Malta Drag Racing Association, with recent high ranking Maltese dragsters in official FIA European championships. There is also autocross (ASMK), hill climb (Island Car Club), motocross, karting and banger racing championships.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
        <a href="#cite_note-242">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta also hosts a
       <a href="/wiki/Snooker" title="Snooker">
        snooker
       </a>
       round, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Malta_Cup" title="Malta Cup">
        Malta Cup
       </a>
       , which as of 2008
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       became a non-ranking event.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2009)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       In 2008 Malta's
       <a href="/wiki/Tony_Drago" title="Tony Drago">
        Tony Drago
       </a>
       was a member of a victorious European
       <a href="/wiki/Mosconi_Cup" title="Mosconi Cup">
        Mosconi Cup
       </a>
       team, which was played in Portomaso, Malta.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2009)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Claudio_Cassar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Claudio Cassar (page does not exist)">
        Claudio Cassar
       </a>
       was
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_world_eight-ball_champions" title="List of world eight-ball champions">
        World Blackball Champion
       </a>
       in 2014.
      </p>
      <p>
       Boxer
       <a href="/wiki/Jeff_Fenech" title="Jeff Fenech">
        Jeff Fenech
       </a>
       is of Maltese descent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
        <a href="#cite_note-243">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Recently contact sports such as
       <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">
        Boxing
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Kickboxing" title="Kickboxing">
        Kickboxing
       </a>
       have become increasingly popular.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Malta is a good place for surfing and offers a lot of different surf spots.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
        <a href="#cite_note-244">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During winter time most of the beaches transform into surfer hangouts.
      </p>
      <p>
       Along with other sports, tennis is a popular activity in Malta and Gozo. The islands offer a wide range of options for both beginners and elite players. Clubs are spread out across Malta and games are being played on a regular basis all year around.
      </p>
      <p>
       There are over 1,200
       <a href="/wiki/Rock_climbing" title="Rock climbing">
        rock climbing
       </a>
       routes in Malta. The island offers a mixture of both
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trad_climbing" title="Trad climbing">
        trad climbing
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sport_climbing" title="Sport climbing">
        sport climbing
       </a>
       and also offers a good variety of
       <a href="/wiki/Bouldering" title="Bouldering">
        bouldering
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deep_water_soloing" title="Deep water soloing">
        deep water soloing
       </a>
       . The geography and small size of the island makes the climbing easily accessible. The sport is growing in popularity with local communities, as well as tourists and visitors.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Boċċi is the Maltese version of the Italian game of
       <a href="/wiki/Bocce" title="Bocce">
        bocce
       </a>
       , French
       <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A9tanque" title="Pétanque">
        pétanque
       </a>
       and British
       <a href="/wiki/Bowls" title="Bowls">
        bowls
       </a>
       . Other than certain differences in rules and the ground on which the game is played, one of the most obvious differences between Maltese boċċi and foreign equivalents is the shape of the bowls themselves which tend to be cylindrical rather than spherical in shape. Many small clubs (usually called Klabbs tal-Boċċi in
       <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">
        Maltese
       </a>
       ) can be found in Maltese and Gozitan localities, and are usually well-frequented and are quite active on a local and European level.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="Your explanation here (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
        See also
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">

        </span>
       </span>

         <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center">

         </span>

        </li>

      </div>

       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
       <ol class="references">

         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">

           </a>

          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Maltese+sign+language+to+be+recognized+as+an+official+language+of+Malta&amp;rft.pub=The+Malta+Independent&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.independent.com.mt%2Farticles%2F2016-03-17%2Flocal-news%2FMaltese-sign-language-to-be-recognized-as-an-official-language-of-Malta-6736155052&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMalta">

        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-nso.gov.mt-2">

           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>

             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-nso.gov.mt_2-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>

             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-nso.gov.mt_2-2">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              c
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-nso.gov.mt_2-3">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              d
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131203033602/http://www.nso.gov.mt/site/page.aspx?pageid=588" rel="nofollow">
           Census 2011
          </a>
          . National Statistics Office, Malta

        <li id="cite_note-39">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-39">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Victor Paul Borg (2001).
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=o1QO1Tk-FsMC&amp;pg=PA331" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             Malta and Gozo
            </i>
           </a>
           . Rough Guides. p. 331.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-85828-680-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-85828-680-8">
            978-1-85828-680-8
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Malta+and+Gozo&amp;rft.pages=331&amp;rft.pub=Rough+Guides&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-85828-680-8&amp;rft.au=Victor+Paul+Borg&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3Do1QO1Tk-FsMC%26pg%3DPA331&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMalta">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-ReferenceA-40">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-ReferenceA_40-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20140914/local/So-who-are-the-real-Maltese-.535578" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             So who are the 'real' Maltese
            </i>
           </a>
           .
           <q>
            There's a gap between 800 and 1200 where there is no record of civilisation. It doesn't mean the place was completely uninhabited. There may have been a few people living here and there, but not much……..The Arab influence on the Maltese language is not a result of Arab rule in Malta, Prof. Felice said. The influence is probably indirect, since the Arabs raided the island and left no-one behind, except for a few people. There are no records of civilisation of any kind at the time. The kind of Arabic used in the Maltese language is most likely derived from the language spoken by those that repopulated the island from Sicily in the early second millennium; it is known as Siculo-Arab. The Maltese are mostly descendants of these people.
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=So+who+are+the+%27real%27+Maltese&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.timesofmalta.com%2Farticles%2Fview%2F20140914%2Flocal%2FSo-who-are-the-real-Maltese-.535578&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMalta">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-41">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-41">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           <i>
            The origin of the Maltese surnames
           </i>
           .
           <q>
            Ibn Khaldun puts the expulsion of Islam from the Maltese Islands to the year 1249. It is not clear what actually happened then, except that the Maltese language, derived from Arabic, certainly survived. Either the number of Christians was far larger than Giliberto had indicated, and they themselves already spoke Maltese, or a large proportion of the Muslims themselves accepted baptism and stayed behind. Henri Bresc has written that there are indications of further Muslim political activity on Malta during the last Suabian years. Anyhow there is no doubt that by the beginning of Angevin times no professed Muslim Maltese remained either as free persons or even as serfs on the island.
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+origin+of+the+Maltese+surnames&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMalta">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-42">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-42">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>

           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-4013-5186-7" title="Special:BookSources/1-4013-5186-7">
            1-4013-5186-7
           </a>
           .
          </cite>

        <li id="cite_note-50">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-vm_66-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <i>
            Roman Times
           </i>
           . visitmalta.com
           <a class="external free" href="http://www.visitmalta.com/en/roman-times" rel="nofollow">

          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Roman+Times&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.visitmalta.com%2Fen%2Froman-times&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMalta">

        <li id="cite_note-77">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-77">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Blouet, B. (1987) The Story of Malta. Third Edition. Malta: Progress Press, p.37-38.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-78">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-78">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="/wiki/Robert_Montgomery_Martin" title="Robert Montgomery Martin">
           Martin, Robert Montgomery
          </a>
          (1843).
          <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=yDQGAAAAMAAJ&amp;pg=RA1-PA568" rel="nofollow">
           <i>
            History of the colonies of the British Empire
           </i>
          </a>
          , W. H. Allen, p. 569: "Malta remained for 72 years subject of the emperors of Germany. The island was after the period of Count Roger of the Normans afterwards given up to the Germans, on account of the marriage between Constance, heiress of Sicily, and Henry VI, son of the Emperor Friedrick Barbarossa. Malta was elevated to a county and a marquisate, but its trade was now totally ruined, and for a considerable period of it remained solely a fortified garrison."
         </span>
        </li>

          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a href="/wiki/Ben_Weider" title="Ben Weider">
            Weider, Ben
           </a>
           .
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160312073211/http://www.napoleonicsociety.com/english/Life_Nap_Chap12.htm" rel="nofollow">

           </a>
           .
           <i>
            International Napoleonic Society

           . Archived from
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.napoleonicsociety.com/english/Life_Nap_Chap12.htm" rel="nofollow">
            the original
           </a>
           on 12 March 2016.
          </cite>

          </a>
          , MED Magazine (February 2005)
         </span>
        </li>

          <a href="#cite_ref-Jones_217-1">
           <sup>
            <i>

          <cite class="citation journal">

        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Concise+History+of+Malta&amp;rft.place=Msida&amp;rft.pub=Mireva+Publications&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=1870579526&amp;rft.aulast=Cassar&amp;rft.aufirst=Carmel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dc3nJnQEACAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMalta">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <img alt="PD-icon.svg" data-file-height="196" data-file-width="196" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/62/PD-icon.svg/12px-PD-icon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/62/PD-icon.svg/18px-PD-icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/62/PD-icon.svg/24px-PD-icon.svg.png 2x" width="12"/>
        <cite class="citation encyclopaedia">
         Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911).
         <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri17chisrich#page/507/mode/1up" rel="nofollow">
          "Malta"
         </a>
         .
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica_Eleventh_Edition" title="Encyclopædia Britannica Eleventh Edition">
           Encyclopædia Britannica
          </a>
         </i>
         .
         <b>
          17
         </b>
         (11th ed.). Cambridge University Press. pp. 507–514.
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Malta&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.pages=507-514&amp;rft.edition=11th&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1911&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fstream%2Fencyclopaediabri17chisrich%23page%2F507%2Fmode%2F1up&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMalta">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <cite class="citation book">
         Francesco Balbi di Correggio 1568 translated Ernle Bradford (1965). "chapter II".

          The Siege of Malta 1565
         </i>
         . Penguin 2003.
         <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">

                        <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="120" data-file-width="180" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Flag_of_Zurrieq.svg/23px-Flag_of_Zurrieq.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Flag_of_Zurrieq.svg/35px-Flag_of_Zurrieq.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Flag_of_Zurrieq.svg/45px-Flag_of_Zurrieq.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
                       </span>
                       <a href="/wiki/Filfla" title="Filfla">
                        Filfla
                       </a>
                      </li>
                      <li>
                       <span class="flagicon">
                        <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="125" data-file-width="188" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/MelliehaHTML.svg/23px-MelliehaHTML.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/MelliehaHTML.svg/35px-MelliehaHTML.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/MelliehaHTML.svg/45px-MelliehaHTML.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
                       </span>
                       <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Island" title="St Paul's Island">
                        Saint Paul's Islands
                       </a>
                       (Il-Gżejjer ta' San Pawl)
                      </li>
                      <li>
                       <span class="flagicon">
                        <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="125" data-file-width="188" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/MLT_G%C5%BCira_flag.gif/23px-MLT_G%C5%BCira_flag.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/MLT_G%C5%BCira_flag.gif/35px-MLT_G%C5%BCira_flag.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/MLT_G%C5%BCira_flag.gif/45px-MLT_G%C5%BCira_flag.gif 2x" width="23"/>
                       </span>
                       <a href="/wiki/Manoel_Island" title="Manoel Island">
                        Manoel Island
                       </a>
                       (Il-Gżira Manoel)
                      </li>
                      <li>
                       <span class="flagicon">

                       </span>
                       <a href="/wiki/%C4%A6alfa_Rock" title="Ħalfa Rock">
                        Ħalfa Rock
                       </a>
                       (Il-Ġebla tal-Ħalfa)

                       <span class="flagicon">

                  <tr>
                   <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="3" style="text-align:left;">
                    <div>
                     <div class="plainlist">
                      <ul>
                       <li>
                        <sup>
                         1
                        </sup>
                        <a href="/wiki/Island#Oceanic_islands" title="Island">
                         Oceanic islands
                        </a>
                        within the vicinity of Europe are usually grouped with the continent even though they are not situated on its continental shelf.
                       </li>
                       <li>
                        <sup>
                         2
                        </sup>
                        Some countries completely outside the conventional geographical boundaries of Europe are commonly associated with the continent due to ethnological links.
                       </li>
                      </ul>
                     </div>
                    </div>

                  <tr>
                   <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2">
                    <div>
                     <ol>
                      <li>
                       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China">
                        Special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China
                       </a>
                       , participates as "Hong Kong, China" and "Macao China".
                      </li>
                      <li>
                       Officially the Republic of China, participates as "
                       <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">
                        Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu
                       </a>
                       ", and "Chinese Taipei" in short.
                      </li>

                                  </li>

             <tr>
              <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2">
               <div>
                <span style="font-size:97%;">
                 Note:Territories and related divisions are in
                 <i>
                  italic
                 </i>
                </span>
                <sup>
                 <small>
                  1
                 </small>
                </sup>
                <a href="/wiki/List_of_transcontinental_countries" title="List of transcontinental countries">
                 Partially
                </a>
                in Asia, or entirely in Asia with cultural links to Europe.
                <sup>
                 <small>
                  2
                 </small>
                </sup>
                Member of the
                <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
                 European Union
                </a>
                .
                <sup>
                 <small>
                  3
                 </small>
                </sup>
                <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">
                 States with limited recognition
                </a>
